description:
18.08.17.          First of many

The Bay Area is blessed with many 
     unique cuisines ... 
In latin, med, asian counties some dishes.        
     Are similiar ...
I Iove to sample unique dishes ... 
     Regional specials ... 
This place offers some ...
     Yeman dishes
author: S.K. Y.

description:
What can I say besides excellent! 

Ahmed our server was beyond hospitable. We felt welcomed, and as if we were apart of the Yemeni culture. 

Amal, the female server really made the place shine, she was nice, and answered all our question to best suit our needs because we didn't know what to get because it all looked so good. 

Walid, Malek, Radfan, and Also walid.
author: Will L.

description:
We placed a pickup order via the Yelp app that was supposedly "confirmed" but actually hadn't been received by the restaurant when we arrived there, 20 minutes later. It turns out that they don't have an electronic system for managing orders, preferring fax via a service called EatStreet. That evening, the fax system was down and so EatStreet phoned them up to make the order - but they didn't manage to get through...

In any case, the host took our order once we worked out what had happened and we decided to eat it there instead. The restaurant was almost entirely full of Yemeni customers (presumably breaking their fast after sunset) and so it took a little while to get our food. 

The decor of the restaurant is relatively authentic (at least what I'd imagine a typical Middle Eastern place would look like - I've never been to Yemen).

It was well worth the wait though. We ordered a classic dish called "Saltah" made with chicken that was hot enough to burn the lining off of our mouths, but was spicy, flavourful and the perfect thing to dip the fresh bread in. 

The lentil soup that we also ordered was relatively bland but tasted fresh enough.

I'd go back!
author: Sunil S.

description:
Worest food I have ever eat! 
We ordered chicken shawarma, lamb mandi and sheesh combination. The shawarma was bland and doesn't belong to shawarma at all. It was a had cut small pieces of chicken cooked in a pan. The mandi wasn't traditionally cooked as it supposed to be cooked in a hole underground with the rice. It was a piece of boiled lamb with some rice! The kofta was burned and dry. Same with sheesh kebabs and chicken which supposed to be cubes of juicy meats but it was a thinly sliced cut of meat that was dry and hard to bite. Very disappointed!
author: M K.

description: Authentic Yemeni food , convenient location. I love Yemeni food and this place is a must try if you want authentic Yemeni food.
author: Madhu J.

description: Shawarma sandwich is 10/10!!! The chicken breast was fresh and cooked perfectly. It was the perfect temperature to eat, such that the creamy tahini sauce and the warm juicy chicken made each bite perfect. There was some crispy crunchy lettuce too to enhance the experience ;) the bread was chewy and soft, thin yet filling... not a regular pita / Laffa I've had before. Loved it! We tried the falafel as well which was good, but the balls were a little dry. Definitely have the shawarma!
author: Tatiana N.

description:
I'm sooooo in love with this Yemeni Restaurant. First time when I went there I ordered Fahteh and rice. This time I ordered mezza platter for appetizer,  Fahteh and the entree mentioned on the top of their menu. 

Mezza platter came with Tandoor Bread (goshhh soooo good), hummus (very delicious and creamy), baba ganoush, banana leaf thingy and salad. It was really good specially with that price. Totally worth ordering it. 

Fahteh ahhh my favorite. I can eat Fahteh for the rest of my life. The bread cooked with the lamb tastes really good. Highly recommended. 

The vegetable and veal entree was pretty good as well. But my personal opinion is that both Fahteh and that tastes pretty much the same. I wouldn't recommend ordering both at the same time. 

Overall nice people, nice service. It feels so homie because everyone knows each other, it's like mini Yemen in that restaurant.
author: Sumbal A.

description:
We've never actually had Yemeni food before. On a whim hubby decided we should try lol 

They ran out of chicken shawarma so I ended up getting beef shawarma. It was so so good. So moist and soft! I'm usually not a beef fan in general but totally loved this! There wasn't that much meat in my shawarma though. It was a lot of lettuce! 
I asked for hot sauce and got a green salsa looking sauce which was also really good. Spicy! 

Hubby got Lamb mandi. The lamb was so soft. But had too many bones according to my husband lol he likes just meat! We've only tried Mandi once in Dubai UAE so we weren't sure what to expect. It was different. But still good. Rice were below average. 
Server was nice. Lady cashier was also nice. Place is decent. Big space/ Mostly clean lol.
author: Amy K.

description:
After the lackluster experience at Yemen Kitchen I was on the lookout for another restaurant with Yemeni food. A quick search on Yelp threw up Yemeni Restaurant so I decided to give it a try a couple of days ago. Yemeni Restaurant is located in Lower Noob Hill so there is no need to shoo off pan handlers on the way so definitely a step up. 

To keep things simple I decided to get the same dish that I got at Yemen Kitchen namely the Saltah ($6.95 small +$3 for lamb and veggies) which is the national dish of Yemen. It consists of vegetables and roasted lamb cooked in a clay pot that is topped with whipped fenugreek. I ordered ahead using the app on Yelp and landed up there after 20 minutes.

I was expecting a small hole in the wall but Yemeni Restaurant is a decent sized place. Unfortunately at the peak lunch hour on a weekend there was only one person eating in. Good news is that my order was ready and I was on my way.

As soon as I opened the container my entire room was filled with a strong aroma which indicated that this was prepared the right way. As it had a ton of fenugreek I thought that its bitterness would overpower the dish but that was not the case. The lamb was a little chewy but stopped short of being overcooked. The saltah came with naan bread (unlike the cheap store bought pita that I got from Yemen Kitchen) actually it was a little crispier than normal naan bread so was more like a tandoori roti. Overall this was a good dish. 

Price-wise it was pretty cheap and comparable to prices in the hood (Tenderloin). Service was fast, ordering was painless. Looks like I've found my preferred place for Yemeni food so will be back periodically to sample more stuff off their menu.
author: Ahmad J.

description: Food is good just service sucks. I ordered a take out dinner and asked for their sauce. The person in the front of the counter mentioned they had put sauce in the bag and wanted to charge me for extra. I said one was fine. When I got home there was no sauce in the bag. Kind of pathetic for them to charge $12+ for a meal and not even double check if the sauce is in the bag or not before wanting to charge extra.
author: Da W.

description: Very frustrated with their service as they did not have chicken when we visited, and we couldn't order the stuff we drove from San Jose to the city for.
author: Ahmed N.

description:
Really good food and excellent service. I ordered the Shwarma. It was perfectly cooked and seasoned just right. The service was the best part. I work across the street and will be coming back here soon. 

They close during times of prayer but when they are open they are totally worth it.
author: Kat D.

description: How anyone could rate this above 2 stars is beyond me. The quality is awful, the price is extremely high, their take out is miserable and the serving sizes are so small... I wish this place was better.
author: Ninja R.

description: Went there with a friend. We ordered the chicken plate, chicken Shawarma, tabuleh, falafel and baklava. The chicken plate and shawarma was wonderful but the falafel were kinda over fried and really hard. The tabuleh was kinda bland and had no lemon juice. The baklava was really dry and had little bit of syrup in it. The costumer service was good.
author: Mario L.

description: Came with big group of people with very different tastes. There were plenty of options on the menu so everybody found something they enjoyed. My most recommended dish is the mandi hadrami. Also enjoyed and would order again the foul madames (fava beans), liver, special ghallaba mix, special fahsa, okra, kabsah chicken, and of course the malawah bread.  We weren't huge fans of the lamb dishes (tried lamb soup, lamb chops/mathbi, and lamb agada). Enjoy!
author: Marina N.

description:
Don't be deceived by this well hidden gem. This restaurant serves one of the best Middle Eastern food in the Bay Area. I always order the Lamb Kabsa when I go here, which has a great balance of taste, and includes the best basmati rice. My coworkers get their lamb shanks, which seem just as good as their Kabsa. The waiters who work here are also very friendly.

The only downside is the food coma I get at work after.

Overall, I would definitely recommend Yemeni Restaurant if you are craving Middle Eastern food in lower Nob Hill.
author: Chris P.

description: Really good Yemeni food. Got a new cuisine to explore. It's not the traditional Mediterranean cuisine. Really liked the taste. Definitely would recommend the Fuul Madames.
author: Rikin M.

description: Great place. Lamb kabsah and chicken mandi is awesome. Just tried the milk tea, it was good with cinnamon. Comes out pretty fast, still nice n hot. Customer service was not that great but not bad. Ill go back again and again to try different dishes. Oohh and one last thing, portions are pretty big.
author: Uuganbayar U.

description: Yelp won't let me bump them up from five stars, but they have taken deliberate measures and upped their game, so karma earns them an update: Read what I said below, and it's all still true, except the part at the end about going when you have a few extra minutes. They have now changed their ordering system so everyone orders and pays at the front, and they have more floor staff waiting and ready to get everything from kitchen to table quickly and take care of your needs. Lovely people with a lovely restaurant, who very much deserve your business!
author: James D.

description: I will say it was my first time tasting Yemeni food nonetheless I have had middle eastern food and it's never been bland as this restaurant.
author: Rick O.

description:
This restaurant was disappointing. I ate here a few months ago and the service was poor, the bread was burnt, and the house specialty soup tasted off and salty. On top of that, the service was very slow even though the place was almost empty. At one point the server's friend brought us a dish but didn't know what it was.

Also, weirdly there was a covered urinal in the women's restroom. Like, ok?

The place has potential if they invest in improving the interior and become more attentive. The food itself wasn't terrible and SF residents like cool new ethnic foods. I heard the original owners sold it or something like that so it may just be going through a transition.
author: Stefanie K.

description:
It hurts me to give low stars, however this is because of the food. 

My husband and I came here for dinner as we walk by here all the time, and had it out on our list of places to check out. The ambiance inside is what I would imagine old school Yemen households to look like, as it it full of character. The server who helped us was sweet enough to walk us through the menu of what popular Yemen dishes we should order. 

On to the order. My husband ordered the saltah with chicken, and I ordered a vegetarian sautee. My order was quite tastey, as I asked for it to be "spiced up" a notch, along with asking for a side of their own house made hot sauce (delish)! My husband enjoyed his food while we were there, but felt that the saltah was a bit on the saltier side. Fast forward 30 minutes later when we got home, he was in the bathroom reliving his dinner experience. 

Something about that dish caused adverse reactions to his system. We will not be coming back.
author: Tracy C.

description:
I tried this place because I could smell the spices walking by. Everything I tried there was amazing! It was my first time trying Yemeni food and I was really impressed. I can't say for sure, but it felt like an authentic introduction to Yemeni food. My table was the only one speaking English, always fun.

Try the Yemeni milk tea, it's delicious and somehow only $2.
author: David C.

description:
Definitely felt authentic! Came here after reading the SFGate's article on Yemeni food and I just had to try. 

Parking wasn't too bad since it's in a quieter part of the tender-nob. Inside, pictures of Yemen/Middle East decorate the walls while music videos from the Middle East show on their tv. Went for lunch and it wasn't really busy but I knew this place had authentic food from the steady stream of Middle Eastern men, most of them dining solo. 

Started with the maraq ($1) - lamb broth soup which reminded me of miso soup since it was clean without any fatty residue. (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=_M1DqDEZx2k24g1onEAQUQ&userid=pDfL8xt8F8ls0-kQIG_ADg)

Falafal ($5) - 4 pieces and these were more pancake like in shape with a denser texture than a typical Mediterranean falafal. 

Saltah $10 - Our waitress suggested this Yemeni traditional dish which is like a braised lamb soup. It came to the table bubbling and the flavors of the tender lamb reminded me of Indian cuisine but softer, not as bold and complex. A comfort food type of dish. 

Chicken gyro plate ($11) - came with a bunch of fresh veggies and the chicken was more chicken strips than the gyro that comes on a spit. Just ok. 

Finished the meal off with some Yemeni red and milk tea which had a hint of sweetness. ($1.50 each) 

If you want an authentic taste of Yemen here's your place. Bring your quarters for the meters, not your passport.

I'd come back to try this grilled lamb dish that everyone else was ordering.  Here's the link of the SFgate article. 

http://www.sfgate.com/food/eatup/article/Eat-Up-Yemen-Kitchen-serves-up-a-taste-of-home-6591802.php
author: Earl G.

description: We ordered the Shrimp Ghallaba and Ghallaba Chicken. Both are excellent!
author: Judy H.

description: We stayed across the street at Hotel Carlton. Came over for some snacks. It was 4:00 and quiet but the server couldn't have been more lovely.  Hummus is creamy and perfect. They offer you this delicious hot sauce too and gigantic piece of flat bread. Felafel delicious too.
author: Rachel V.

description: Tried to order on Yelp. Long wait so tried to cancel but Yelp not responsive and difficult to get in touch with customer service. Until an hour later when they called to tell me it was closed in the first place. Terrible all around and I'm done with both.
author: Roy H.

description: Prices are really high here !!! I don't know what it is with the food that is special but prices shouldn't be as high as it is here. A bowl of rice and chicken for almost $14 ???? Else where only $10.
author: Emad A.

description:
Best food, perfect job guys!!!
Do it guys what you do it !!!
Delis he's I like you kitchen...
Best of Fuckin San Francisco
author: Stephanie A.

description: The Saltah(lamb version) and the tandoor bread are my favorites! My go-to place.
author: Arjun n.

description:
This my favorite restaurant in town. If I can give more than 5 stars I will do. I highly recommend it if you want to try Yemeni food. The food is very tasty and fresh. They have a good service and their stuff are very nice.

Thank you guys :)
author: Osama H.

description:
Double, double toil and trouble; 

Fire burn and caldron bubble. 

Saltah.


It will heal your sickness. And perhaps that of the world.
author: Joe D.

description:
This is my first time trying Yemeni food...and it was such a good experience!
We tried the tanour bread (probably prepared in a tandoor like oven, similar to tandoori bread). Noticed that reviews had mentioned that it had burnt bits of the bread.. But they might not have known that this bread is prepared that way... Anyway, it was so delicious straight out of the oven.
The hummus appetizer was simple and flavorful. Exactly what we wanted, in terms of quantity and flavor. 
The shakshouka, reminded us of a breakfast preparation called egg bhurji we've had at Indian restaurants. Once again it was delicious and flavorful! 
We also got the chicken mandi hadrami which had basmati rice and spiced chicken. The rice was so good as is, with no accompaniment necessary. 
The free hot tea complemented the food perfectly. It was very sweet and we didn't need to add any additional sugar. 
Our server, who may have been the owner was so gracious and welcoming brought us some hot sauce... Which again was so good (and so hot) we got some to go with us. 
All in all it was an amazing introduction to Yemeni food. I would most certainly be back. The $$ yelp rating is fairly accurate. 
Portion sizes are good. We had leftovers which we took to go.
author: Louisa D.

description:
Yemeni restaurant is the best restaurant in the town, fresh food, great service. I highly recommend if you want to try the Yemeni food. 

Good luck!!
author: Mohammad D.

description: After hearing so much about this place, I finally got the chance to go while visiting and I must admit, I was not impressed! We went a little late and I felt like I was eating left overs. Slow service and the food was just ok. I was kind of sad leaving because I didn't have the best experience. Maybe next time?
author: Anah M.

description: A well kept secret!! Great staff and the food was outstanding! A friend and I decided to meet there before heading to Grace Cathedral for a holiday music show. We ordered the volcanoe bowls. Mine was lamb and vegetables. This was served with a large piece of what looked like naan. The spices in the dish were a winning combination and the flavors were so unique and delicious. A real winner and very inexpensive!
author: Ola P.

description: I went there for breakfast and As an a Arabic guy who taste alot of yemenese food I can tell you there food were pretty average for me except the bent Al sahin it was really tasty ( I recommend you not too miss it ) but the other dishes like foul and massoab we're not as I expected . There service was perfect and very helpful .
author: Talal A.

description: I'm not sure if I ever wrote a review for this or not. But literally, this is not Yemenis food. This was plain shit. I order 100+ worth of food for my family and I,  thinking I was going to get some authentic food like back home. But nope,  this was gross. Worst food I had. I got sick from this shit for days. I repeat days. This shish was gross everything on that menu is disgusting.
author: Nurarihyon H.

description:
A few of my Arabian Uber drivers recommended this place so I was like cool and checked it out.

Food: Good apps, bland entrees
-Hummus was surprisingly good and smooth, best I've had aside from Oren's in south bay
-Saltah, aka a stew considered the national dish of Yemen, looked like a stone pot of puke but was fairly flavorful with a bird spit texture
-House flat bread went well with the hummus and saltah, thin and stretchy
-Mandi Hadrami, aka baked lamb, lamb itself was tender but didn't have much flavors
-Chicken Kabsah, aka yemeni fried rice, also contained barely any flavors until I culinary-geniused the leftovers in my kitchen with truffle oil and five spices powder

Service:
-Decently nice meek server

Setting:
-Spacious and okay clean with harsh fluorescent lighting, no sexy ambiance for a try-hard-not-to-try-hard date, better suited for a casual platonic meal.
author: Tian Q.

description: This is probably my favorite restaurant in town. Amazing  traditiona yemeni l dishes with great service.
author: Amal A.

description: It's the best Yemeni Resturant in the bay area good and delicious food and good service I recommend it to anyone looking for Yemen he tastes food and Mediterranean food
author: Abo A.

description: I discovered this restaurant via the Allset app, and was pleasantly surprised by the ambiance. It wasn't so packed for a weekday lunch, and had a good selection of tasty foods to choose from!
author: xmarksthespot y.

description: Food was great and I love their tea. I would give this restaurant 5 stars but the only reason why I rated 4 is because of their. It was the same when I ordered a couple of dishes
author: Mohammed B.

description: I order the lamb Haneed , was so Delicious and excellent cook , also the service was excellent I recommend to go back.
author: Nabil F.

description: Very authentic. Try the lamb shank for the salta thick stew. Amazing baklava and mango fruit desert
author: Steven S.

description: Excellent food, fresh and delicious. Great service. We came here during Ramadan, had a shorter version of the menu, but still, these guys know exactly how to prepare a tasty meal.
author: Maciej L.

description: The food is great, very friendly staff, and the prices are very good especially compared to SF, and the desserts (paklawa) was really tasty. I wish they will stay forever!
author: Mustafa A.

description:
Two stars are for the okay service. The food was very disappointing. 

Dropped by after seeing good reviews and wanting some authentic Middle Eastern food. We ordered the Arabian meza platter of hummus, grape leaves, tabbouleh, and labneh, falafel, and a chicken shawarma sandwich. The grape leaves were decent, the labneh (yogurt) was flavored and tasted like cucumber, which I'm not a fan of. I wish they'd put some zaatar (thyme) on it but I guess that's not a Yemeni tradition? Hummus was creamy and okay but not amazing, but the bread was nice, except for the burned parts on it. 

The falafel was by far the worst and most flavorless I've ever eaten at a Middle Eastern restaurant. It tasted like dense sand. I'm not sure how they managed to make falafel with zero flavor (not even salt was present), but they did. I could tolerate only one bite. The chicken shawarma was mediocre as well.

Overall, we were disappointed in our meal and won't be returning.
author: L. S.

description:
Pros:

Great bread 
Great soup 
Only place I've seen in SF that has Vimto

Cons: 
Food was only ok, and wasn't totally what we expected (partially our fault, though the menu wasn't 100% clear).
Some of the food was honestly too hot to eat for a good 30 minutes (really loved up to the term "volcano pot"). 


Overall, we came in with high hopes and were a bit disappointed. This was our first time trying Yemeni food, and it wasn't all I'd hoped for, unfortunately.
author: Zach H.

description:
As we were in SF on Thanksgiving we wanted a reminder of home, for we voted for Arabic food. My Chicken Kabsa was fine, service was okay, And the atmosphere was not very comfortable. We were being starred at by the staff, probably because we were Middle Eastern ourselves!! Nonsense.
Three and half Yelps!
author: Sari A.

description: The food was very good which I give 4 stars but the service was not the most welcoming. The lady in from just sits there and gives you a stare; not even a happy hello thus 2 stars. Overall 3 stars
author: Mimi L.

description:
This place was previously called Yemeni's Restaurant, not sure if it's the same management, but look at yemeni's restaurant pictures for an idea of what the food here looks like since I forgot to take pics.

Food was good, especially the ghulaba chicken, the lamb saltah was alright but the meat is so tender than it becomes very shredded, and the ghorma came in a pot with a good amount of meet but not super flavorful. 

Based on the food alone I would have given this place a 4, but the service was very poor. People who came after us were getting their food. There was a large lag time between when we asked for something and actually got it. And lastly we also ordered a chicken dabagh or something like that, and weren't told that they didn't have it until all our food came out. Our food also take an unusually long time to come out. First we were given our saltah after maybe 30-40 minutes then after at least another 10-15 minutes the other two dishes came out. They didn't tell us that our dish was unavailable until the last two dishes came out. 

I do think that the restaurant was understaffed which may have contributed to some of the issues. If they could fix some of these issues this place would be a 4 or a 5.
author: Saadiya R.

description:
Five stars for the food. I love the kofta kebab. The rice and salad are great too. Hummus is smooth, not the thick kind though. I love their sahug, lately they make it very spicy. 
And the lamb soup is the best!
author: Jacob E.

description: Ordered the chicken shawarma plate to go. When I got home there was no sauce on the chicken and they didn't add any to the bag. The chicken is a good portion but pretty dry and there's nothing redeeming about the side salad or rice.
author: David N.

description: AWESOME.  Really enjoyed the food and dining experience. Relaxed atmosphere, no rush.  Authentic in every way.  Can't wait to come back next week. Chicken and rice is delicious.  Salta is wholesome.  Tasty stirfried chicken strips with spices.   Appetizer platter.  Best homemade flat bread ever.  Fresh super spicy homemade chili condiment, ask for it.  Give this place a try.  Life is too short, what are you waiting for?  Can't forget their flat bread...
author: Lola M.

description: The staff is very friendly and the hummus is good. However the main course, lamb hadrimi, was very bland. No spiciness at all.  The entire main course was just like boiled pot roast and veggies. Sorry but I will not return.
author: John C.

description:
A nice subtle place. Great ambience with free tea! 
I loved the Chicken gallabha with the bread. Rice was good too! 
We keep coming back here:-)
author: Shahul H.

description:
My friend and I were initially interested in going to Saha, but the two-hour wait eventually steered us across the street to this Yemeni restaurant. The interior was large, spacious, and filled with Yemeni customers of all ages. Upon entering, there was a two-tier platform overlooking the open floor and cash register. Lighting was a tad bright for dinner, but the trade off was the feel of authenticity in the air.

The Hummus with Tahini ($4.50) came with a generous portion of creamy hummus served with tanour bread. The bread was a bit thicker and dense than pita, and the hummus was smooth with a chickpea flavor without the zing at the end. The bread was served warm and easy to peel by hand. I've had better hummus elsewhere, but this was a solid beginning.

The Chicken Shawerma ($10.95) consisted of marinated chicken, rice, and veggies. The chicken was tender but the marinate was quite subdued. The rice came with generous portions, but there were noticeable clumps that made it unpleasant. I don't recommend it.

The Haneed ($12.95) came with a large bulky piece of roasted lamb served with rice and veggies. The lamb was soft, tender, and easy to fork into. This dish usually comes with a plethora of spices, but the flavors unfortunately were held in check. It was a decent dish, but could be improved. 

Our servers were very generous to treat us to their version of Rice Pudding. It was served warm with rice, raisins, and milk. The consistency was thick and custard-like. It was a nice dessert to complement our hot Yemeni Tea, or also known as Adani ($1.50). 

Service was warm, hospitable, and friendly. In all, portions were very generous and the flavors could be much more robust with refinement. The Rice Pudding was a nice gesture, and prices were solid for the area that we were in. 2.5 stars. I will have to visit other Yemeni restaurants before deciding whether to return.
author: Daniel L.

description: Absolutely the best hummus I have ever had!  The chicken shawarma sandwich and the falafel sandwiches were huge and so delicious!  Very casual and not too busy.  Service is friendly, polite, and efficient.  Very casual setting.  Don't forget the hummus.  And then get an extra order to go - you won't be sorry!
author: April M.

description:
The Yemeni restaurant is back to its greatness. Since the new owner took over the quality and consistency of the food is phenomenal. The meat is tender and perfectly season. The service is good but if it's busy there is a 10-20 wait food.
Great food!!!!!!
author: PJ L.

description: Food is great! Ambience is not really good (kind of stinks), but I would take it given the amazing food and exceptional people who work there!
author: Prathik G.

description:
I went with my boyfriend and we both got food poisoning.

The servers were nice, but provided very slow service. I'd say we would've gotten out 20+ minutes sooner if they'd been more attentive or moved quicker.

The food was poor. The meat was over cooked in both dishes and the rest of it was subpar. The soup I had was seasoned well, but I didnt care for the rice it came with or the meat and vegetables in the soup.

And again, we got food poisoning. My boyfriend barely touched his food and I tried to be a good sport and eat as much as I can. We both got stomach aches and I ended up projectile vomiting that night.
author: Cheryl W.

description:
The food and service here are incredible. It's a family run place with authentic Yemeni food. I can't say enough good things about the young men who run this place. They are all so polite, efficient, and  
very welcoming. 
We started with the lentil soup which was excellent. The mezzanine plate was also very tasty. My husband and son were raving about the lamb mendhi, it was literally falling off the bone. I had the veggie salta and that was delicious as well!!! We also had the mango juice, it was by far the best mango juice I'd ever had! It tasted more like a cocktail you'd have on the beach; it was across between a juice and a smoothie- so refreshing! The staff here definitely takes pride in what they do.
If you're new to Yemeni food, definitely ask your server what they recommend. Go out on a limb and try something new. Best of luck to this place and Thanks for such a great experience.
author: Amel F.

description:
It is a decent restaurant that serves Yemeni cuisine. Based on my visits, the waitstaff was friendly, but service was kinda of slow.  The place seemed dead. Not too many customers.  The place lacks ambiance.  I tried the Saltah (the national dish of Yemen).  It was OK.  It was basically a meaty stew.  I would recommend stirring the stew, before eating it.  Stirring it brings out the subtle flavor of the dish. The Tanour oven baked bread (sort of like Nan bread) was good.  I also tried the Malawah bread (sort of like a buttered Nan bread), which was very good.  It was moist and tasty.  The Mandi Hadrami (baked lamb dish) was very good.  The lamb meat was moist and tender. I think they use lamb rib meat. I think it is their best dish.  Kabsah Lamb (Yemeni Lamb Biryani) was above average.  It was not amazing. I think Kabsah is also the national dish of Saudi Arabia.  The Masoob (a warm creamy bread and banana Yemeni/Saudi pudding) was OK.  The serving was huge, but the presentation was lacking.  The Yemeni milk tea was good, but a kind of pricey. I got charged two dollars per 8 ounce cup I drank during my last visit. 

Overall, a nice place to visit if you want to explore Yemeni/Saudi cuisine. The servings are huge.  I would not recommend coming alone.  A lot of the dishes are sharable. Customer service is a bit lacking. Decent food, but nothing really amazing except for the Mandi Hadrami.
author: Hiroshi K.

description: If you want to talk about good talk about that Yemeni Restaurant. The sauce is amazing. The traditional dishes are to die for. I love this place. I honestly visit about twice a week. (I work in the area, don't judge me). But even if I did it I would commute just for their food.
author: Mohsen M.

description: This place has AMAZING food and the service was great as well. The lamb chop dish was delicious, I loved it!!!
author: LoLi H.

description: Wow- I've been wanting to try this place forever and finally got to go. It was delicious! We got the milk and banana drink which was amazing and two vegetarian dishes: falafel and a vegetable sauté. The vegetable/ rice dish had amazing flavor and I will definitely get it again. The table next to us got a really good looking dessert, but we were so full I couldn't order it. I'll have to go back just for the dessert- they are open until 10pm.
author: Lindsay L.

description: Yemeni's is currently providing free meals for protestors against the Muslim ban and those detained in SFO. We need more businesses like this to step up for humanity. Thank you guys
author: Jessica N.

description: This was my first time trying Yemeni food and I was so glad that I chose to. Service was impeccable. The staff was attentive, warm and welcoming. The food was absolutely delicious. I ordered the Saltah with lamb and vegetables, which came out bubbling and with a side of bread. The staff came by and explained how the dish is traditionally eaten. I could not get enough, the flavors were perfect. I also ordered the baba ganoush which was a great starter. The ordering method is a little different than other restaurants and you order in the front, find your seat, have your food and don't pay until you leave. Make sure to grab a cup of their free tea before you leave the restaurant! Overall, 10/10. Will definitely return whenever I'm back in the area.
author: Janit S.

description:
First things first, LAMB. Anything with lamb is an excellent choice here! You won't be disappointed!

I brought some friends to try Arabian food for their first time and this was definitely the best place to bring them. If you haven't tried Arabian food yet, come here and experience Yemen 

Excellent service! And don't forget the tea!
author: Anisa A.

description: This place is disgusting. I felt like I was eating leftovers. The place was very filthy as well, there were bones everywhere. It wouldn't kill them to clean their tables.
author: Jasmine O.

description: Excellent food at this restaurant! Cheers to the owner who donated food to the protest at SFO today! Delicious chicken, rice, hummus and pita!
author: Elizabeth F.

description:
The owner of this restaurant brought the lawyers and protestors food at SFO in the wake of 45's executive order. He brought his adorable sons too :-)) he said he would come every day to support us. Truly an inspirational man.

Now for the food, it was delicious and gobbled up by us all. I am a veggie so enjoyed the hummus and super moist rices. But the chicken dish was the crowd favorite.

Thank you, sir.
author: Meghan M.

description:
I have been coming to Yemeni's Restaurant for about seven years and they've never failed to impress me with their amazing food, good service and good prices.  My favorite dishes are the lentil soup, the Meze platter, topped off with any lamb entree. I recently had the the lamb haneed, and the meat was so juicy and pulled right off the bone! 

I went there today to celebrate my birthday and they accommodated my 14 guests with no problem. They served us rather quickly for such a large order.  The service was great as usual. An additional 5 guests arrived as we were leaving and they let us order for delivery!

I love love LOVE this place.
author: Maylen R.

description:
I'm really not sure I know what Yemeni cuisine is, but it apparently falls under the convenient umbrella of Middle Eastern food which probably does this type of food a great disservice. It's probably like presuming Korean food is not much different than Chinese or Japanese food. Cultural ignorance and xenophobia abound in this cold world, so it is my personal mission to discover the unique cuisines in this city, one restaurant at a time. You can thank me later. So there are actually two Yemeni restaurants on the same block - the fancier Saha, which I haven't tried yet, and this modest corner operation (photo: http://bit.ly/14ctfFb).

I've seen it riding past on the 2-Clement line, so I wanted to give it a shot. I entered at 6:30 on a Monday evening to a nearly vacant, triple-tier space (photo: http://bit.ly/15XwITY). I waited about five minutes before one of the waitresses, perhaps the only one, acknowledged my presence at which point I was told I could sit anywhere I want. I sat at a table on the second tier only to be told it was not set, and so I was told to sit somewhere else. I walked down to the main floor where I sat at a table with a setting. At that point, I waited another five minutes for a menu. I started feeling unwelcome until the owner stopped by and asked me whether it was the first time I dined here.

I said yes, and then he described all the house specialties (photo: http://bit.ly/14ZMfWP), which was great but then I waited another five minutes for the waitress to take my order. Based on the owner's recommendation, I went for the $12.95 Mandi Hadrami, which turned out to be a lamb shank baked in its own juices in a way that recalled osso bucco. It came with a side salad and a scoop of the house rice (photo: http://bit.ly/1bz8gzb). It was pretty good though I frankly like lamb shank in any culinary style that's presented to me. I just thought the dish as a whole was on the bland side, and I think I will need to try other Yemeni dishes to give this cuisine a fair shake. Next time maybe I'll give Saha a try.

FOOD - 3 stars...a good lamb shank, just nothing that makes me shout from the rooftops
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...atmospheric in here
SERVICE - 2.5 stars...well, uhhh...the owner was nice
TOTAL - 3 stars...is Yemeni cuisine the new black?...not quite
author: Ed U.

description: Chai was amazing, but the meat and rice portions definitely need more work. The beef with Palau was pretty great, but the biryani style dish barely had any meat in it. Would've given this 3 stars, but adding that extra star just because of the chai
author: Rafat N.

description: I tried lamb haneeth and mandi, they were OK and meat was tinder but tasted far away from typical Yemeni food. Also Masoob was missing its authentic taste.
author: Mo M.

description: Very disappointed because of the good reviews we read! After a long day my colleague and I went to order dinner to go and relax in our room. I ordered some hummus and a lamb mandi and bread. The hummus was missing in the pack, the bread was burned but the lamb was excellent. The lamb was big chunks with rice and nothing else. My colleague got a sandwich that had a funny smell and could not eat. Her lamb soup was just a blend lamb broth. Her salad was ok but to small for dinner so she had to order dinner from the hotel room service. We will not go back and do not recommend this restaurant.
author: Cecile L.

description:
It's good. I'm not sure if I would come back here though since I've been to many other middle eastern restaurants that I've LOVED.  First off, I showed the waitress which chicken dish I wanted based on one of the pictures I saw I yelp. She told me that it wouldn't look like that and that it wouldn't have the carrots, radishes,  etc. on it. When I compared what I got and looked at the picture on yelp, it seemed to be missing a lot of stuff.  The baba ghouoush (sp?) was ok too. 

I did like how they had hot chai tea for you before you ordered. It's a self service so you can get as much as you like. 

When it all comes down to it, this place is good. My friend seemed to have really liked it and said he loves the authenticity of this place. The only way I would probably come back here is if I was in the area and I was super hungry and craving Mediterranean food.
author: Loreto D.

description: Every dish is incredible . Tastes authentic and home made . The staff is very friendly and courteous despite being ridiculously busy. Will def be back!
author: Lulu E.

description: This is quite the hidden gem. Very friendly wait staff, good tea and deliciously spiced meat and vegetable dishes.
author: David M.

description:
We expected epic Yemeni food. Denied, and all served up with poor service to top things off.

The falafels were as hard as a rock, the bread fell flat on flavor, and the hummus was so mediocre. Sabra could've kicked this hummus' a**, no problem. The salad was ok.

Then it happened.

They forgot two of our entrees. The waitress didn't even apologize and seemed annoyed when we asked if the two remaining chicken entrees were on their way. Reasonable question, after all the rest of us were almost done with our entrees. 

They weren't even worth the wait. Blech.

Don't waste your time. Stay away.
author: Gabriela W.

description: The waiter was super friendly and accomodating, i had hummus, chicken mandi hadhrami and marag (lamb soup), everything was good but the portions are HUGE so if you're a small/ petite person, make sure you bring a friend with you to share. Food needs more salt also. Overall experience was good, but I'm only giving 4 stars since my soup had a tiny piece of hair in it (i dont even wanna know where it came from lol)... But yea, i ate it anyway
author: Cathy M.

description:
Avoid this restaurant at all costs. I had one of the worst dining experiences of my life here. I visited this restaurant around the end of the year (2015) while in the city with my family. 

The waitress did not come by to help our table for at least 20 minutes. We called her repeatedly but she did not budge. Instead she helped other customers that arrived later. She would repeatedly nod and tell us that she would come soon but did not. After we ordered my family probably waited over a hour to get our food. Also, our food arrived much later than other customers who arrived after our party. When the food finally arrived I come to find out the waitress did not take my order. She did apologize and provided a complimentary meal. However, the food was terrible. The lamb and chicken kabob were dry, hard, overcooked, and the rice has no flavor at all. In summary, this was a very poor dining experience.
author: Edris E.

description:
Spoiler alert: It's a restaurant that serves Yemeni food ;) But really, for the Middle-eastern foodie-illiterate, all you need to know is that they have baba ghannouge  and kebab and lamb stew -- all the good stuff.

The staff in the restaurant was very helpful -- giving us tips on what to order, and accommodating our loud group. 

We started with the appetizer plate to share. It's got the staples -- tahini, baba ghannouge, falafel, and grape leaves. They all tasted decent, but nothing really to rave about. The bread/cracker they serve with it was my favourite part of it.

I had one of the actual Yemeni dishes, which was the roasted lamb. The seasoning tasted good, but the lamb itself was quite stringy and tough. Hmm...not a big fan of it. The plate did come with a whole load of food though, so if you're a big eater, you don't need to worry.

I ordered their tea, because I'm a big fan of Middle Eastern style teas and it didn't disappoint. Too bad their food didn't really shine as I was hoping it would.
author: Alice C.

description:
Come here and get your Fattah on!

Now, if you don't know what Fattah is, get it anyways. I had no idea myself particularly since there is a version with meat. Turns out it is dessert. At least the one we ordered was. Fattah with dates and bananas. Delicious and indulgent and totally worth splurging on. I believe it is basically shredded baklava with dates, bananas and cream on top. Mmmmm

The place is ultra casual. No decor, plain, cheap. But the food is so good! And the prices are very reasonable. I met a friend I hadn't seen in over 20 years here and she says this is the restaurant she always eats at when she's in the city. I can totally see why. Pure comfort food. If you are Yemeni that is. I am half Arab myself but had never had Yemeni food. Many of the items on the menu overlapped with familiar foods, but there were definitely things that were new to me (Fattah!) and items prepared differently than the way I was used to. This is definitely a cuisine worth knowing. 

Items I would highly recommend other than the Fattah that is. Get the Tanour bread. It is amazing. Get the Yemeni trout. Also amazing. My friend ordered the Baba Ghanouj. I like the Palestinian/Lebanese style more, but personal choice...Tea was also good but be aware that they sweeten it. This is traditional if you are Arab. 

I want to come back and try more Yemeni specials!
author: Nora S.

description:
This restaurant is located in Tenderloin neighorhood.
I went to there Sunday lunch for two.
We had one sampler and one lamp shanks.

(Rating: +++ is perfect)
Atmosphere+++:
I felt like I am at Arabic country  inside the restaurant.

Service+++:
Pretty kind and friendly. 

Value+++:
Reasonable
_________________
Food

Sampler with yemenl's bread +++:
This is a kind of appetizer.
There are two different dips, yogurt,  chickpea, parsley couscous salad, a Falafel. When I taste them with a bread, they made a nice harmony. I love it.

Lamp shanks+++: 
Lamp was super soft I've ever eaten.  The rice have a good saffron smell.

Both were excellent.

After lunch, I drank a little bit sweet cinnamon tea. Then I could be refreshed.
author: Hiromi S.

description:
Lamb Haneed. I can't eat enough of it. I'm from Brooklyn and there was a Yemeni restaurant I would go to nearly every week to have the lamb. Since I moved, I hadn't found a restaurant to help satiate my cravings, until now. I came in at 1130 and the waitress was really nice. She let me know the Haneed wouldn't be ready until 12. I almost didn't stay, but I'm glad I did. Lamb was tender, and tasty
The price is a little expensive, but the portion was large so i still think it's worth it. 
I took one star off because the soup was a little watered down and they charged extra for bread that should be served with the food.
author: Omar J.

description: I eat a lot of middle-eastern food, and when visitng San Francisco, I wanted to see if I could find something different from my usual Lebanese or Iranian fare. Yemeni food certainly fit the bill.  A new owner, and his family, took over the restaurant about seven months ago, and from everything I hear, it's much improved. It was clean and the food was excellent. Outstanding was the La Sanaa Maza, a mixed appetizer plate.  The Lamb Mandhi Hadrami, marinated with Yemeni spices was terrific, as was the Chicken Hadrami. Nearby, people had a scrumptious tasting Ghallaba with beef that I'll have next time. They have some great bean dishes that are under the "Breakfast" menu, but are terrific any time: Foul Mudames (mashed fava beans, sautéed onions and tomatoes), and another dish called Fassoulia (white kidney bean sautéed with onions and tomatoes).  For San Francisco, prices are cheap.
author: Laurence D.

description:
I stopped by this place with a group of friends when the owner stopped by my coffee shop and told me to stop by for a good time and great food. 

To say that I had a great time and that the food was delicious is an understatement. Moses, the owner made this place feel homely and welcoming. I've never had Yemen food ever in my life and I have to say he set the standard high. 

As soon as we all sat down, he told us to disregard the menu and to trust his taste and ordered us a round of dishes he calls home and man-did he deliver. We ordered a soup dish as a starter then a couple places of meat dishes and they were impeccable. 

If you're looking for a neighborhood spot where you set your hat down and have good home cooked meal, stop by here. They will treat you like a guest in a home and Moses will make sure of that.
author: Teresa C.

description: The most delicious hummus i've ever eaten. Authentic Middle Eastern cuisine. Highly recommended.
author: Kirill N.

description: Very good restaurant! The food is delicious and the stuff is very polite. I will definitely come back to his place! Whatever you order tastes do good! 5 out of 5!
author: Nastya M.

description: Tonight was the first time I patronized this restaurant and unfortunately the last time . My wife and I walked in around 8:45 pm . It took about 2 minutes of awkward stand i in the entrance of the restaurant before I had to ask the employee if we should seat ourselves . She replied by saying that we can sit anywhere we like ... so we sat . We ordered one appetizer and one entree to share. It took 47 minutes before our appetizer showed up (the mezza ) . It took a little over an hour before our ONE entree (burma lamb) showed up . The bread that came with the appetizer was hot and fresh . The appetizer wasn't anything special . I'm pretty sure the stuffed grape leaves were canned and the labne was sour cream ( they may fool some but you can't fool me ). Anyhow , I was pretty upset for the extra long wait for the food , actually , I was furious. I couldn't understand why ??? There was like three maybe four customers in the entire restaurant. I controlled my temper , came to pay the bill , the cashier asked me "how was everything?" When I told her how we definitely weren't happy with the fact that we had to wait over an hour for our food , she simply printed my receipt , handed me a pen and stayed silent . I swear she didn't even try to say sorry , not even a word came out of her mouth !! SMH , this is the type of service that gives Arabs a bad Rep , shame on you YEMENI RESTAURANT .
author: Izzaldin M.

description:
We ordered delivery from them last Wednesday for dinner.  We had the following: Lamb liver, Arabian Saute vegetables, Shawerma chicken and a small lamb and vegetable Saltah.  

First off, we've never had Yemeni cuisine before so was looking forward to trying something new.  But when we received our order, we noticed that the description on Seamless for the sautéed vegetable dish was very different compared to what we actually got.  On the menu, it was supposed to include zucchini, potato, eggplant, green pepper and onion with homemade red sauce, for $10.  What we did get was a tiny portion of sautéed green pepper and onion (maybe 3 tablespoonful), sans sauce, over rice, which was not mentioned on the menu.  So this turned out to be a very expensive side dish disguised as an entrée with the addition of the rice.

The chicken dish was topped with cream sauce which was not mentioned on the menu.
  
The lamb stew was quite bitter, something that I am not sure should be the case.  I also later read online that this type of dish should be accompanied by some type of bread, which makes sense considering that it's more liquid than anything else.

The lamb liver turned out to be the winning dish for both of us.  Though it was also presented differently to us than described on the menu, julienned instead of cubed liver, the meat was very tender, flavorful and not at all gamey as we feared.

So, all in all, everything was edible, but nothing really wowed us.  I definitely won't be ordering another vegetarian dish from them again.  Or maybe we'll just check out another Yemeni restaurant the next time.
author: Yvette F.

description:
I went back to this place on day after Christmas and I have a very similar experience with the user: Roget G. 

I was waiting for two of my friends' arrival. However the servers did not seem to care to stop at my table and ask if I needed anything to drink or any appetizer. After numerous attempt, I was able to catch one of the servers and while asking for a mint tea he mentioned it'll take a while for the tea. I was okay with it since I was waiting for my friends anyway. However he showed up in a matter of couple of minutes with a lukewarm tea which I could already tell was not a readily prepared tea. 

I went on and ordered my lunch - a lamb kabsah which I have had it here before. The food arrived very quickly and I could tell the the plate was just reheated to be served. When asked for their spicy chilly sauce, the guy offered me chilly ketchup! Who eats ketchup with Arabic food!?! 

Very frustrated with the service and the quality of the food, I refused to eat at this place and left. 

I do not recommend this place any longer. If you're looking for some serious Arabic or Middle-Eastern food, look somewhere else, or even out of the city.
author: Rabab M.

description:
Arrived at 7:45 ! Was waiting for about 10 minutes to be seated! No one even came , after that we was ordering and half of the menu is finished! So we decided to order another stuff ! 
Once we ordered the waiter came after 30 minutes and said we have to wait another 30 minutes cuz the stuff is eating there dinner . 

It was my first and last time 
Will never go back to this place again
author: Mosaab T.

description: solid middle eastern food. the ful is very tasty. and all for a reasonable price. solid 4 stars.
author: Ruben K.

description: The worst experience ever, idk why they call it a restaurant, it's like food for my dog, there were rice all around the table it is like an accident happened there, i'm sorry but it was disappointed
author: Abdulaziz A.

description: I really wanted to like this place, the reviews were good and I love arabic food. I've worked in fine dining and casual dining for many years and I am extremely disappointed by this place. I was clearly profiled because my small order (2 soups) took them nearly two hours to make. Other customers walked in and out with their food while I patiently waited. I have never felt so disrespected. I would never order food from here again.
author: Andrew M.

description: Restaurant decoration depicts Yemen culture n history on entrance door. Their food was  good in taste, well presented n flavorful. Tea is complimentary. I don't know how much cups I drank there. Tea is good in taste.
author: Yummy T.

description:
I am rating this restaurant 5 stars not for the good service, but for a great girl, who is the only person doing a great job in the restaurant, her name is Sara, she is doing an excellent job and she is very helpful.
I do have many things to say to the owners of this restaurant, first thing; tables remain unclean after people finished eating, sometimes they serve you food and they don't even clean the tables before putting food on them, they also do not provide drinking water with meals, also almost everytime I go there is no-one at the reception desk which take you a long time to be helped or seated.
To be honest, over all the quality and quantity of the food is very good, but they need to improve the customer service.

Thank you again Sara for the great job you are always doing and I wish you all the best.
author: Jose E.

description: Went for take out dinner last night. No one else was there and my food came quickly. I ordered the chicken Kabsa and an order of hummus. The chicken dish said it was sauteed chicken with rice, scallion, onion and spices. I assumed it was boneless chicken but I was incorrect. Bone in pieces which were very moist and tender. The rice was delicious and the meal was plentiful. The spices were good and not overpowering. All and all this dish was a winner. The hummus was tasty but different than any other hummus I have ever had. I can't quite describe the difference although it was runnier than most hummus I have had and I would say it didn't taste very chickpeaish. The tanoor bread was delicious although I don't think I would order the hummus again.
author: Linda M.

description:
I had been wanting to try this place ever since it opened, and finally got the chance on a recent Indian Summer evening. My dinner companion hesitated when he realized that they do not serve alcohol, but I was able to appease him with promises of an after dinner drink at the Fly bar across the street.
When we walked into the brightly lit dining room, we were warned that the credit card reader was on the fritz and it was cash only. The restaurant is divided into two sections, the one in the back is elevated a bit. Although there were only a few diners in the lower section, we were ushered to the very back of the restaurant, where it was a bit lonely. undaunted, we ordered our dishes from the lovely waitress.

The highlight of the meal was the meze platter - exquisite hummus and baba ganoush. The Yemeni bread was also a treat.

The entrees were pretty basic, nothing too memorable.
My dish, the Trout (Yemeni Masqoof) 12.95, was fried but still light.

The marinated Boned Chicken Roasted Chicken 11.95 was prepared well, but a bit bland.

We would definitely be back for more appetizers - especially since we found out about their byob or wine policy.
author: Carole B.

description: Food is amazing! I especially enjoyed the lamb dishes we tried. The best Yemeni food I've ever had!
author: William J.

description: The best food ever .. It's a Historical food . You will love it .. But make sure that you try all kind dishes here ..and you will love it . So bad
author: Zeyad A.

description:
Their rice is like no other. It's aromatic and is cooked with a perfect blend of spices to give it a flavor I have never experienced before, and I love it. All the meat that I have had there has been in my opinion, cooked to perfection. Having said that I've only had lamb there. 
It's hard to say what is my favorite of the things I've tried, but the lamb liver appetizer I think I might get every time and it comes tastes homemade bread. If you get a chance try the lamb soup too. It's only a dollar and it's well worth it. I think it's a broth made from lamb drippings, but I'm not totally sure. And try their tea too, it's sweet and delicious. 

People on this are saying the service isn't good, but I have had no problems so far. The waiters come enough, but not to much to where they pester you. They will answer any questions you might have. I think maybe the everyone else is just a snob. 

This is now one of my favorite places now.
author: Timothy C.

description: This is one of my favorite restaurants in san francisco. Prompt service and food is delicious. The chicken and beef Ghallaba are my favorite dishes! Highly recommended.
author: Aziz E.

description:
This place was recommended by an Uber driver.  Last time we followed up on such a recommendation, it was spot on but this time it was almost a complete fail.  The food was somewhere between mediocre and good, but the big letdown was the service.  We sat with empty glasses for almost 10 minutes.  Our entrees came out staggered, and so staggered that we thought that two of them were running 15 mins late.  Finally we hailed them and they realized they completely missed two of the entrees.  Evening came to a screeching halt. 

The place is pretty spare and lacking, so it all kind of fit. Pass.
author: Saminda W.

description: This is my favorite restaurant in the city they have the best food ever the make you feel that your in Yemen the. If you want to eat good food and experience a  Yemenie culture come to this place. Their food is crazy delicious they also have the best employees that's make you a warm welcome.
author: Sabri A.

description:
Wonderful service! I came in because my internet was not working at my house nearby. i told him my situation and he let me order a tea and use his wifi. The best!

Adding on to this review: The Owner surprised me and brought me out a sampler of sauces and some flat bread.

Again, the service was wonderful and I will definitely be coming back.

-Amanda
author: Amanda C.

description: One of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco. The food here is so tasty but the chicken saltah has to be my all time favorite dish. Service can be a bit slow but they are extremely friendly. Will definitely be returning more and bringing friends!
author: Lakambini O.

description: We happened to stumble upon this place and I'm so glad we did! Their huge flatbread not only looks amazing, but tastes amazing. The lamb is large and so tender. Texture was perfect.  There weren't many people there when we went but don't let that deter you. This is an affordable, casual, authentic, and tasty restaurant.
author: Kay T.

description:
I had to come here and write a review for my recent experience! It is my second time here. First time was back in 2012, food was ok back then, service wasn't great at all. 
I have to say they have improved a lot. The food is excellent, as authentic as it gets. The service is excellent too. We have ordered Mandi (my favorate dish in Yemen) it was excellent, Fahsah similar to saltah but only yemeni people can tell the difference it was great, chicken kabsah was great but I didn't like the taste of cilantro in it as it is not used in the original dish and chicken should have been cooked with the rice not separately (but still very good). 
If you are looking for a great Yemeni food, this is the place to go. To be more specific, if you like Lamb this is the best Yemeni style lamb you can get in California.
All in all it was excellent experience, I finally ate the food I am craving for years. I have to say that the Eritrean girl was so friendly and just complimented my experience there.
My only complaint if I had to say it, is that i live in the central valle, and don't come often to SF, and when I do most of the times it is Ramadhan and they close during the day.
author: Naif B.

description: Real authentic arabic  Yemeni food ( most customers are From Yemen . Just stick with signature lamb and goat dishes , really delicious . Ask for extra salsa type side sauce . Rice really good but I like with lot of sauce .
author: Mete C.

description: Service is slooooooow. Food was not bad, but not as amazing as other Arab places.
author: Hamed A.

description:
Ive been to Yemen kitchen for lunch and it was super packed, we waited not too long and got seated. You can see the guys cook the food there and they are all nice and welcoming. The food was amazing there. 
Hence, I was excited to try this place since it looked pretty decent on Yelp.
We had a lot of expectations for this place .

1)the service was way too slow, we waited probably an hour to get our food.
2) It was super cold in the restaurant. It was okay when they finally closed the door.

The main part was the food, we asked for recommendations
1) lamb Kabsah - it was most rice with Yemen spices.there was barely any meat in there. Now when you're paying $15 for a dish you better expect some good meat in there.
2) mixed veggie dish - once again so much rice and the veggies were okay.

The service was so slow, we waited for about 30 minutes to receive the check and pay for it.

If you're looking to eat some good food and feel welcomed try Yemen kitchen.
Even though it is small and doesn't have a sit down restaurant vibe, you will be satisfied.
author: K S.

description: I have been coming to SF for year but never tried to check what else is out there. The place is nice and spacious. The food was great, I got lamb liver, lentil soup and mandi. The service was fast and the bread was fresh. The price was good as well. I will be coming back.
author: Mohamed E.

description: I came back Tues night and tried the baked lamb. It was tender and moist. It came with the same yummy rice and salad. I called it in, and took it back to my hotel. I am glad this place isn't in LA, or I would gain a ton of weight eating here all the time. Service is quick and friendly. Will definitely come again and again when visiting SF.
author: Lynne A.

description:
Yemeni's Yuminies.  This place is A-OK in my book.  The woman operating the front cash register was as inviting as could be.  Upon ordering our food she offered us tea and helped guide us through the menu as we were ordering food to go.  The chicken dishes we ordered, although similar, were both stellar.  The Falafels could have used a bit more tender love and care considering by the time we ate them they were a bit dry and had hardened about 20mins into finishing them off.  Part of me wanted the comfort of grease and sloppy food, but I have to say that Yemeni's was none of that. Although the food tasted great it was a bit more on the healthy side of things...

Trust me, I'm not complaining about this place as it was truly authentic Yemen cuisine, but I wish a little more love went into each dish, like what we expeirenced while we waited.
author: Kevin J.

description:
I came here again this past weekend, and I feel like the quality has dropped somehow. 

The waitress did not have a good grasp of English, and could barely understand me when I said to bring out the food when it's ready as we were in a rush. 

We ordered the falafel appetizer and salmon filet to share. The falafel was quite dry, and seemed like it had been made hours beforehand. It just wasn't quite as fresh as I had remembered. The salmon filet was also cooked to a well done state rather than the medium salmon that I had and really liked the last time. It looked like a large piece of the crispy skin had stuck to the pan and peeled off. I almost couldn't believe they had the guts to serve that to a customer. The portion also seemed smaller than before, and it came with a side of lettuce, which looked pretty sad. It came with a brown rice, although I remember a white rice sprinkled with orange the previous time. The waitress didn't ask us whether we wanted brown or white rice. I thought the white rice was a bit more visually appealing, although the brown may be slightly healthier. 

I'm not sure what happened to Yemeni's, but the quality has really declined, I'm sorry to say. Too bad, because this used to be a reliable option with good value food.
author: Audrey L.

description: Portions are really generous and they slowly cook all the meat they serve which comes out delicious and beautifully soft.
author: Tarik K.

description:
This place had almost ruined my birthday. I made reservations for 15 people a week before we were coming. The day before I called to make sure everything was going smooth.  The day we came in,  the lady at the front says there is no reservation on the schedule. Um, what? !?! I just conformed it the night before! 

Moving on,  after a bit of arguing,  we are finally taken to be seated. They wanted to seat us in different areas. I had to fight with them over bringing the tables together so we could sit as one group. 

We all start to order after waiting for way to long. I don't remember what I ordered (it wasn't fish ) but when the food cobalt arrived,  I got fish. I didn't order fish.  I told the waitress/hostess that I didn't order fish to which she responded that they made me this instead of what ever it is that I ordered at the time because they were out of it. Once again,  um, what?!?!

Maybe I'm too high maintenance but my experience is that if a restaurant is out of something,  they let you know and ask what you would like instead. Not decide for me.  

Long story short,  no apology, no discount,  plenty of bad service. 

I give two stars only because my friends told me that their food was slightly better.
author: Miriam G.

description:
NEVER RECEIVED FOOD

I ordered on GrubHub, received a text that the food was on its way and an hour and a half later it's still not here. The place is a mile from my home. Unacceptable.
author: Kara P.

description:
Came to work in San Francisco for a month for a tourist event. Had to find a Middle Eastern restaurant for some of our customers. Needed large orders every 4 days. Looked on yelp and found this restaurant nearby. Best decision I ever made.

Food - Our orders consisted of Haneed, Tanour Bread, and Sauteed Vegetables. Received excellent feedback from all of our guests. Very delicious.

Service - excellent. Restaurant owner Moses offered to deliver the food to our hotel for no extra charge. 

If you are looking for middle eastern cuisine in San Francisco, this is the place to go.
author: Robin S.

description: This place is absolutely authentic! I suggest to stay away from mezzas-hummos,babaghanouj and etc.  Stick to their lamb dishes! The restaurant can be decorated a little better but overall the food entrees are large in portion and tasty! Highly recommend!
author: Noor S.

description:
really amazing, I don't think i've ever been disappointed coming here.  The food is always on point and the service is great. 

They've changed the menu a lot in the past year but they still offer the same great food.

The free sweat tea is amazing, bummer you can't just buy it at the store, apparently there's like, 50 different ingredients (according to our waiter).
author: Tu T.

description: The air was stuffy. Like I had no air. The decor was nice but it was hella dark. The wait staff was not dressed the same. One wore a jersey, the other wore an entire Arabian outfit. Based off of that, it lacked consistency. I ordered the shesh touk. The rice was very bland and dry. You'd think because it was colored orange, it'd have some sort of flavor but no. The meat was incredibly dry and flavorless. The one thing I did enjoy was the Tanour bread, hummus, yogurt, and Baba Ghanoush. Over all not impressed. Two out of five stars, and that's only because the staff was nice, and the water was clean, and so were most of the utensils.
author: Furwa K.

description:
Please do not go.
Never take your guests there unless you wanna give them a horrible experience. The dishes are expensive and the servers acts as if you owe them a favor to sitting in their dated hole in a wall... 
I was charged a $1.50 for a piece of flat bread to eat their $13 flavorless mezza plate. The $15 main dishes looked like freaking breakfast and dinner leftovers mixed in a bowl and heated in a microwave. 
I ordered a lamb Kabsa and got chicken Kabsa instead  (I kept it just to avoid unconvincing their highnesses) which had bits of chicken breast and chicken bones burried under the poorly flavored mountain of rice..
I took my group of friends who come from Sudan, Egypt, Iran, and Lebanon, we personally promise that this is the poorest and most disappointing representation of Arab hospitality and cuisine. 
Didn't even finish my plate and left with a $95 bill.... did I tip? Yes, of course as the server intimidatingly stood over the bill waiting for me to write down their undeserved tip. 

Learn from my mistake, don't ever go there.
author: Roget G.

description: It was my first time coming to this restaurant. I was looking forward to the food. When we went we were hungry, so after looking at the menu, we didn't order much. I ordered, chicken shawarma sandwich, taboula, fries and a drink. The sandwich was good. But I was very disappointed about the taboulah. It was basically made of parsley and cucumber, it shouldn't be called taboula. I also tasted some of my sis soup, the taste was so bland .. Service was little too slow. Other than that it was nice visiting this restaurant.
author: Nemo A.

description:
I had high hopes for this place, but the kabobs were very dry and overcooked.  So was the falafel.  The roasted lamb went over very well with the group, so I would order that if you go.  The hummus and baba ganoush were tasty though.  

I did feel like we were being stared at by staff and customers when we walked in (big group of Asians), which was weird especially for California, but it didn't bother me too much -- everyone was perfectly nice.  I just think they thought we walked in there by accident.  We're from Detroit!  We know our middle eastern food. :)
author: Ji-In L.

description: Its very good place I love it . However , guys please put some heater or try to close the doors. Its always cold here but food is very delicious ! Love this place !
author: Jay M.

description: Downgraded very quick, bad customer service, food wasn't fresh regardless of my 25 min wait. Food was exceptional before but is flavorless and dry now. Soup tasted like water and oil; not coming back. I paid $50 for crap.
author: Vanessa G.

description: Very good and reasonable Yemeni restaurant. I had dolmas, a kind of lamb biryani, etc. Pleasant service. Atmosphere kind of bare bones.
author: Jethro B.

description:
If you are a fan of Near-Eastern/Middle Eastern food, this place might be worth trying -- but only because Yemeni food is hard to come by. It is a hole in the wall and easy to miss; be aware, hygiene is sub-par.  In places like this I prefer to try things I haven't seen before/can't pronounce...but look good. Basically, we stayed away from the shawermas and shish kabobs. 

We thought the Chicken Kabsah was amazing. The rice had lots of garlic and was cooked in really high heat. Tasted like a fusion of Indian Biryani + Thai Fried Rice with a Middle Eastern spin.

Trout (Yemeni Masqoof) was well-cooked and crispy but lacking in salt. The marinade  was good but didn't seep throughout the fish so we had to eat it with the super spicy and yummy Yemeni green chili salsa that was served with our food.

Haneed (Roasted lamb leg) was slightly saucy and huge. It was sweet, savory, and smoky at the same time. Tasty, but we liked the Kabsah most. 

Unfortunately, hygiene and service were lacking. The floor and dishes seemed a little dirty and the waitress, who was quite friendly, didn't actually think of giving us extra plates even though we were eating family style.  Still, I'm glad we walked by this place and stopped here because Yemeni food + culture have definitely been shunned from any positive spotlight thanks to global media and international politics.
author: Arushi S.

description:
I have been to the Middle East and this place is a lot closer!
Seeking the flavors and spices from my long ago trip I found this rough diamond in the rough!  By USA Standards, the restaurant was very casual, but the food was made with real love and attention!  The owner hand grinds and mixes the fresh ingredients daily. Come to think of it, the restaurant was just like the places I went to overseas!  It kind of felt that I was in my buddies house if it sat 50 people.  
Fresh Hummus, Fresh Eggplant, delicious baked/fried trout, most excellent salmon that was crispy and moist at the same time!
The Haneed-huge lambshank was fork tender and delicious! 
Try this place if you want authentic middle eastern food without having to carry your passport.
author: Curtis L.

description: The food is very good it was my first time trying Yemen food and l love it so different but it get me hooked up I keep going there and a lot to choice
author: Sunil M.

description: I have been twice here with family and friends. The restaurant is large and good for a big party. Overall, food is great and very authentic. Service is excellent too. My favorite is the lamb dishes and you can have it family style with other type of meat.
author: Sam M.

description: Great authentic food. More peopel need to go check this place out.
author: Faisal Q.

description: The best food I was there with my friend Moses he took care of us we try the lamb minde and hummus and haneed so got don't forget to try the lamb salta with tanour bread
author: Mo H.

description: Some of the best service I've had in SF - our host was very attentive despite it being busy; he was very personable and went out of his way to bring us free samplers of the house specials and our favorite, the vine leaves! The food was delicious, too.
author: Katherine V.

description:
I am pregnant and I crave this food. If I were not pregnant, I suspect I'd crave this food. When I go to SF, I try to come here. It seals the deal--whether it's a day trip or for a few weeks. 

My last visit revealed: 

The falafal is flavorful--all of the spices you'd expect with a fresh pop. 

The salads are crispy. 

Their trout dish (called Yemeni Masqoof was perfect. You could still taste the fresh trout flavor that was submerged in more of their spices. 

I was given Okra on accident and was it so delicious! It's the way those spices bond together! 

Yes, they know how to do Americanized but also real  Middle Eastern food! 

Sweet, friendly people work there, which always adds to the experience.
author: Jen L.

description: Worst food I've ever had that I'm actually rating something on yelp for the first time. Not only that, it's also really dirty and flies are everywhere!!!!!!!!
author: Raghd Q.

description: Terrible!  We came in and waited ten minutes for a table before being told to sit wherever we wanted.  After being seated, we were given the menu and told what was ready and what wasn't. We asked for the hummus appetizer to start, but nothing came after thirty minutes.  They didn't even offer us a drink.  After waiting 30 minutes, we left and went to halal wings plus next door.  Absolutely horrified by the service.
author: Arsalan S.

description: My fiancé and I stumbled upon this place on the way to another restaurant and we were so glad we tried the food here. We had the vegetarian and lamb saltah with tandoori bread and the food was amazing! My fiancé also got a veal broth on the house and we ended our delicious dinner with a fruit dessert that had mango, pineapple, apples, coconut and pistachio. Overall a great experience, both food-wise and service-wise as well. Staff was very friendly and fun to talk to!
author: Aditi G.

description: Decent yemeni place - doesn't and wouldn't replace my usual haunt on Court Street in Brooklyn (I am a New Yorker), but hey, I am on the West Coast.  You have to adjust.  The Saltah is good (needs more fenugreek), the tanoor is a little skinny, and the tea isn't self-service (tea is a symbol of hospitality, and down in Brooklyn the tea is always available free as a welcome to visitors).  The haneed roast lamb is quite good though.  If I move to the west coast this would be my go-to for a taste of home (Brooklyn, not Yemen).  Too bad I am only here in SF on vacation.
author: Kevin K.

description: It's called Arabian Cafe now. Service was ok. I had to keep reminding her for my juice and food items. Compared to other Yemeni restaurants 1 out of 10 they are a solid 4. The soup was good and the rice but the lamb was very sticky and too much fat. The orange juice was ridiculously small for $3.95. It was a small flute glass. Asked for Nan was was told we don't have any and 5 minutes later she brought out some for another table. Subhanallah! The music was banging loud also. I would recommend another "halal"option someplace else. Authubilah...
author: Shea B.

description:
I remember having to venture through the Tenderloin into the stench of sidewalk pee and wind-blown drizzle of God Knows What...to get to Yemeni's. My friend insisted on walking here, lamenting the days where he would be approached by random drug addicts asking to exchange crack for heroin:

"I mean, DO I LOOK LIKE A DRUG ADDICT?! I started to question that myself...but really, I just told him I wasn't up to date on the current crack : heroin conversion, so I really couldn't offer him anything."

Anecdote aside, Yemeni's is just average in my book. I had some falafel and stuffed grape leaves, while my friend had the chicken shawarma. Oddly enough, the restaurant was quite empty around lunch time--I think we were the only other guests aside from one table. The food was tasty, but nothing memorable that would prompt me to return.

Service was also a bit off--our waitress apparently mastered the art of disappearing because I don't think I saw her at all after she took our order, and it was a task to flag her down for the bill. 

From what I could tell, this block has quite a few Middle Eastern restaurants and markets, so perhaps I just chose a slightly underwhelming one...onward toward my search for legit, mind-blowing SF Middle Eastern cuisine.
