author: Ellie W.

description: This is a disgusting place! I live in the same building as the restaurant is located in and can see from my window everything that is happening and all the smells from the kitchen. Dirty dirty place, oh yeah this place was closed down before for not passing the inspection...there's always weed smell from the kitchen...so if you want your food prepared by some  high cooks you can try this place. I had food there a few times before I found out how dirty the place is...the food is not that great either...didn't seem fresh....seemed very bitter and dry. Read the reviews about people getting food poisoning there...unbelievable! Don't let the decor and "nice" staff fool you.....
author: Ana V.

description:
This place was fantastic. Frankly, I do not know much about Yemeni food, and although I love Middle Eastern food, I am typically ignorant when it comes to the names of the dishes. 

The beef Kabsah was incredible. Huge chunks of beef, flavorful rice and vegetables. There are bones in the dish, which I like, because it means they brought out the full flavor, but proceed with caution. 

The chicken Mathbi was great as well. Nice crispy chicken skin. Perfectly seasoned. This place is legit.
author: Jon J.

description:
Pretty sure I'm gaining extra weight right now because of the rice. I can't stop eating it! Everything else I've eaten has been delicious, particularly the rice, chicken, rice, veggies, and have I mentioned their rice? 

Mmmmm.
author: Loli L.

description: Unexpected and wonderful is what my guests say when brought here. We do food tours in the Tenderloin and this place is always a hit. The food, which is primarily Yemeni is exotic yet familiar in a comforty way. There is a soup called Volcano that comes out in a hot pot and is served to the table as it boils. You eat it family style with pita-like bread, really amazing. I would recommend other dishes but cannot recall the names, I've always relied on the helpful staff and friendly owner when ordering and have never had a bad dish. Highly recommended.
author: Michael M.

description: I'm  big fan of Middle Eastern food in general. Even though of all the recommendations, this place is nothing special. Everything was a little bland sorry to say.
author: Alex O.

description:
Delicious!
The chai is tasty, as is the food.

If you're new, the owner is very helpful in explaining the dishes. Yemeni cuisine is rich and unique, with a wide range of flavors. Highly recommended.
author: Michael M.

description: Horrible ambience. The restaurant was cold with no heating. The food was ok. We did not enjoy our visit to this place at all.
author: Poonam B.

description:
My family and I chose to eat here to celebrate Mother's Day this year, and I'm so glad that we did! We all really love Middle Eastern/Arabic food (since I worked before in Saudi Arabia), and we have eaten at many different restaurants here in US with this cuisine. However, the food we enjoyed here at Arabian Sky definitely stands out among the rest! 

To start off, we were given complimentary lamb soup, which tasted very good, and was also very aromatic, due to the other spices included in the soup. We also ordered falafel as an appetizer. For our entrees, I ordered the Lamb Kebsa, my wife and one of my daughters ordered the lamb shank (which is called "Lamb Haneeb" on the menu), and my other daughter ordered the Shish Kefta. My lamb kebsa was very flavorful, and I was pleasantly surprised with the amount of lamb that was in it, too! I had a piece of lamb in every bite of my kebsa! My wife and daughter were very pleased with their lamb shanks, which were fall-off-the-bone tender. And my other daughter really enjoyed her kefta, too! The entree actually came with 3 keftas, and they were seasoned very well. Both the lamb shanks and the kefta came with basmati rice that was very aromatic and complimented the 2 dishes very well. Also, the portion sizes here at Arabian Sky are very much worth the price! While I was able to finish my kebsa (I enjoyed it so much!), my wife and daughters had to take some of their orders to go! By the way, the food tasted just as good once we ate our leftovers at home as when we were eating at the restaurant itself! 

All in all, we really enjoyed our experience here, at Arabian Sky. The waiters were very kind, and the overall vibe of the restaurant was family friendly. If I had to say anything negative about this place, it would only be that some of the food was a bit on the salty side, and we hope that the chef can reduce the amount of salt in the future. But we will definitely be looking forward to coming back here again the next time we are in San Francisco!!
author: Stanley C.

description: Good authentic food, really nice service. A nice ethnic neighborhood restaurant -- we need to keep these going. It was tasty - the hummus was smooth and the lamb was tender. Felt like eating at your Yemeni grandma's house.
author: Andrew K.

description: A great experience and quality food! Haven't had Yemeni food, I recommend the Maasoob and the Saltah
author: Maryam Z.

description: It's a must place to dine in if you guys looking for Middle Eastern Cuisine. I Totally suggest to have hummus and Tanour Bread, for the main course Lamb Kabsah and yogurt to have it with the dish.
author: Ahmed A.

description: food is authentic.  My kids like their Salta and Kilaba dish.  The bread is fresh from the oven.  The manager and the waiters are very courteous and helpful.
author: Dahlia G.

description:
To be honest, I didn't know a country called Yemen existed.  At first, I thought this was a Greek or mediterranean restaurant.  When I think mediterranean, I think of only kabobs.

I ordered the mandi hadhrami which consists of a generous portion of lamb meat, long grain rice with some brownish color oil for flavor, and small salad.  The lamb meat the waitress gave me was a lamp chop with a bone in the middle but I noticed my friend had many bones with slightly fattier meat.  We asked the waitress and she said it's a different cut of lamb and usually regulars only want a certain cut.  It's hard for me to describe the lamb other than the spices they put on it was tasty since I'm unfamiliar with Yemen food.  With the amount of lamb and rice given, you can easily fall into a food coma so definitely order some caffeinated drinks to wake yourself up.

RECAP: Mandi Hadhrami's lamb can be a certain cut if requested.  I'm sure other dishes can be customized as well.
author: Ronald L.

description:
This is a nice restaurant. Food is usually good. Portions are big, plenty of rice with almost every item. Only problem with the food is that sometimes meat tend to be a little bit dry.

Service is slow at times. I feel like this is because of the waiters rather than the kitchen. But it is not a big problem.

Definitely try "Fattah" dessert. It is the star of the menu.
author: Cem A.

description: Nice restaurant specially for those who looking for halal food. Try the meat kabsa, shakshoka and chicken shawarma.
author: Mishary A.

description: Sooooo delicious... wonderful yummy satisfying food with wonderful service - wonderful people, en- joys!
author: Beth S.

description: This is by far one of our best food experiences in SF. We stayed at Carlton Hotel accross the street and rolled back to our rooms. Try any lamb dish and you will not be disappointed.
author: Adnan B.

description:
No doubt this place is the best middle eastern food in the city. 
The food so delicious and very affordable I've been coming here for over two years now and they always have consistency and great selection of amazing food 
I recommend every one to give this place try 
And the customers service very great as well 
They definitely deserve five stars lol
author: Mohammad Z.

description:
We returned after two years. Let me first say that instead of the owner's wife serving us, we had a young girl who had just started. Last time, re raved over the food and the friendly but slow service. 

The service was still friendly and slow, but this time we didn't have to wait 45 minutes for the food. So slowish but acceptable today.

The food was good but not as great as last time. We had the lamb with Yemeni seasoning.

The disappointment came when we got the bill. They wouldn't accept the restaurant.com coupon we bought last week! They also only took cash because they credit card machine wasn't working.

We probably won't come back.

Good food that is different from other cuisines, but the place tries my patience.
author: Norman M.

description: Wandered in off the street, and relieved to find that the food is incredible. All of the other patrons in the restaurant were clearly Middle Eastern, so that's when you know you've found a good spot. Staff was kind for the most part (one girl was a little rude), but I will definitely be back.
author: Emily A.

description:
Ugh, another place with amazing food and substandard service. 

I brought some friends here for dessert after dinner at Osha, wanting to introduce them to Fattah (warm banana and date mashed together), which I'd enjoyed a couple times before. 

After 30 minutes of waiting I asked our server what was going on. He said they were having problems and it wouldn't be much longer. After 50 minutes of waiting I asked if they could bring us an extra order for free to make up for the insane wait. The server agreed, but apparently his manager refused.

Finally after an hour we got dessert, and our check came out without any discount or explanation. 

Soooo if you go here, expect amazing food but be prepared to wait.
author: David Z.

description: The food was fresh and delicious. The lamb haneed and rice--had an amazing homemade authentic flavor. Great service and affordable price for such a high quality meal!
author: Nicole S.

description: 4 star for food and for service just 1. I experienced very bad service,but again good food
author: Santosh G.

description:
Yummy and a great value as prices are very reasonable for heaping portions. 

The bread is deliciously doughy and the hummus is an excellent way to start off the meal, along with the self serve hot sweetened chai tea by the door. 

The beef kabsah was really tasty. Tender pieces of beef mixed with well seasoned rice and veggies. 

Salteh was a literally bubbling hot heavy clay bowl of soupy (but kind of oily) veggies that came with an interesting whipped veggie mousse and spicy salsa. I didn't love it, but it was a unique new dish worth trying. 

What I had been craving was the fatteh dessert, like a bread pudding but piecey, chewy, and more delicious with honey, dates, banana, and creamy goodness. It did not disappoint! We split one between the four of us... It was plenty, especially as we were all already happily stuffed from the apps and huge entrees.
author: Amy X.

description: The food is made with fresh ingredients we enjoyed the veggie appetizer the most.Ask for the house made green hot sauce when you order. I wish I would have got it before we started inhaling it! Get yourself some complimentary tea on the counter make yourself at home!
author: Jack A.

description:
5 star to previous management. Food used to be absolutely awesome. There were times when i drove from San Jose just for Chicken Kabsah.

But once it changed its name (previously Yemeni) i see a decline in its quality. I hope they make things better as before.
author: nagarjuna k.

description: Having never tried Yemeni food I was intrigued by this place.  The atmosphere was casual and very quiet, but the service was prompt and friendly.  Everything on the menu sounded good so I had a really hard time deciding, but that just means I'll return.  I settled on fish which came with a side of rice and salad and it was all delicious.  Well cooked, properly seasoned, and a wonderful spicy salsa like condiment for the fish.  I was surprised the fish had all of the bones in it since I'm used to it being deboned, but perhaps that is a cultural thing.  It's hardly the end of the world, just a bit awkward picking bones out of my teeth when I'm trying to be ladylike lol.  I'm not sure if they had a dessert menu, but I'll look next time if I have room left.
author: Elixa S.

description:
Came in after work hoping to try out the lamb soup ($2.50).  Not available. Are you serious?  

Was ignored for a few minutes when I walked in. It was a cold night, and they leave the door wide open. Freezing while I'm eating.  Poor service. 

Had the falafel, and the food was great. Flavorful & hot.

Recommend the food, not the service.
author: Mohammed H.

description:
I was craving something hot and/or spicy, and thought to get some Mexican/Salvadorean food.  On my way there, I was about to pass Yemeni's and thought to try it out instead.  So glad!

Firstly, they need to step up their fish game.  At least where they source it from.  I was thinking to get the trout or salmon, but they're both farm raised.  So I went with shrimp, which I assumed was just fine.

Ordered the "Shrimp Ghilaba", with some Lentil Soup, Grape Leaves (Dolmas) to start, and a Vegetable Salta to share with the Mrs.

All were fantastic.  The Lentil soup's flavor was something I'd never experienced, add a little bit of lemon and the complexity opens up a bit for ya.

The grape leaves were nicely packed and delicious.  The Vegetable Salta was hearty, and with a spicy "salsa" on the side, it really satisfied my heat & spice craving.  The Shrimp Ghilaba wasn't anything fantastic, but definitely seemed like a traditional dish, and I enjoyed it thoroughly.

Next time I'm craving some mid-eastern comfort food, I'm definitely coming back to Yemeni's!

SIDE NOTE:  I really hope they're applying for a liquor license.  Would have been great to have an ice cold beer to accompany this meal.
author: Jonathan B.

description: Please stop any attacks on Yemen! The food is too good and would create peace worldwide. Amazing find, recommended by my Lyft driver. Family style restaurant with excellent food that have unique flavors. A first rate dining experience. I ate too much, I couldn't stop.
author: Emily L.

description: Their Kabsah is amazing. One dish is just enough for two people. Although, we usually order extra to eat later. That's how much we love their food.
author: Zain H.

description: As a Middle Eastern myself I think the food here is not authentic, I wanted to order Mandi with lamb but the waiter advised me to have a similar dish " Madghout " and I agreed. The plate was split in half between the rice and lots of lettuce and cucumber or what they call salad. never saw rice and salad served on one plate in Mandi, Kabsa or Madghout before!. On top there was a few pieces of lamb which was flavorless and poorly cooked.  I was very disappointed I left hungry and settled for a Burger later, I will never be back again
author: Maher S.

description:
DETAILED REVIEW. I gave this place 6 tries before I decided to post a review. Since this is one of the only Yemenis restaurants in the bay area I guess they are allowed to set the bar and unfortunately  they set the bar pretty low. For food that is as unique as Yemeni food they should take that uniqueness and integrate it with their decor and ambience as we are all to familiar with the norm of middle eastern restaurants and kabob houses. The place has the look of a typical cheapo Chinese restaurant. In fact I believe they probably got the furniture and interior from a Chinese restaurant because of the leftover cantonese writing I could see in the wood. 

Now for the food. I have been to Yemen many times (Sanna, Taiz, Aden, Hudaida) and something that is common with all Yemeni food is thick pans and searing hot food. I mean soo hot it looks like lava, it should always be this hot as it helps you take your time and enjoy every bite slowly and it brings each flavor and spice to your taste buds. Over here I got cold food, i almost felt like it was a leftover forgotten in the kitchen. The chef also loves salt, my tongue is sensitive to salt  and I left with a sore tongue (too much salt). Also aside from bringing you cold plates, they take forever bringing 1 plate at a time. Usually by the time every last drop is eaten off your plate 10 min later the next will arrive. By the time half our order has arrived I become full from waiting soo long that I just want to leave. 

Service sucks. The place is understaffed or the staff is way unorganized. Not my business so I don't pay attention to their ethics but what bothers me is that :
- They don't write orders for the kitchen, I am always asked multiple times what did I order. 
- They don't care much about you if you are a returning customer or regular
-They never want to help you or check up on you
-THE WHOLE MENU IS NEVER AVAILABLE! They ate always short on something. This bothers me the most, I go because I want to order exactly what I want, not to get the cold salty kitchen leftovers. 

I am tired and can no longer stomach the food from this place. The only thing keeping it open is that it is the only Yemeni restaurant in sf. Its sad that they take such little pride in what they do, being the cullinary representatives of a country most know nothing of.
author: Yosof R.

description:
Lamb chops to die for!  
This place has wonderful food.  I was a little put off from looking at it from the outside, but once I walked in I was stunned.  This is a nice restaurant!   The lady waiting on me was so sweet!   I almost asked if she wanted to adopt me!   

If you are looking for authentic Mediterranean or Middle Eastern food, come to this place.  You won't be disappointed!
author: Matt V.

description: Best Yemeni Food Ever! Love the red tea and Saltah Lamb!!
author: Umber A.

description: Quick update. Decided to come here a few weeks ago for dinner. SO and I walk in...and then nothing. No "seat yourself" sign, nobody to welcome you, just stood there for about 5ish minutes...and then just left. I can't say whether the food is good or not, but the complete lack of service is astonishing. Will never go again.
author: Katia T.

description:
Malawah bread its my favorite, the sampler" appetizer was delicious.
the soup
lamb meat very tender, 
baklava dessert yummmmy

wow every thing was delicious

if you love middle eastern food then you should try this place, if i live in san Francisco i will eat their every day. 

people their very friendly
author: F K.

description:
This restaurant was a much needed oasis on Valentines day....After a failed dinner at a restaurant which will remain nameless...  

Gracious staff welcomed us, gave us the best table in the house, served us sweet hot tea.

We feasted upon succulent chicken nestled in a bed of spicy rice and a platter of fire roasted Kabobs. We were then served a Fattah- a dessert like banana hash covered in cream and honey- a dish so big we could have shared it with an entire band of Yemenese Dancers...

oh and the music was great, the owner came around waving hands, motioning for the volume to be turned up...up! 

Oh we will be back, That I can promise you.

$35 for two.
author: Sarah M.

description:
I eat here frequently and always order the chicken Shwarma.  I've had it about 8 times in the last two months..and each time it is prepared completely different.
I am not sure why...don't get me wrong, it is delicious 9 out of 10 times...
Last night was awful...way too many onions i could barely taste anything else.

Do they have a different chef every other day?
author: Ripley B.

description:
Good food nothing special but it is nice to have some variety in the neighborhood.  

Don't come here during Ramadan though unless the sun has already set because the staff gets kinda cranky and neglectful.  

Its worth checking out.
author: Jacklyn H.

description:
Love this place. Service is great. Food is great. 

4 stars because while it's great some dishes could be better. The ground beef kabob was a little rough. 

But overall, excellent restaurant. You know an Arabic restaurant is good when most of the patrons are Arabs.
author: Mehdi A.

description: Very very delicious and true authentic middle eastern Yemeni dishes.... Hidden jewel that make me drive 5 hours from LA.
author: Ali O.

description: We had a great dinner in this restaurant. We were a group of friends, everyone ordered a different thing, and we shared so that we can try all of them. The most amazing was Lamb Mandi; It was just delicious. They also have that Maasoob dessert that was tasty. The waiter was very nice, helpful and friendly; He even gave us an excellent discount. It's also very close to the masjid, so that you can pray if needed.
author: Amr E.

description:
My girlfriend and I walk in on a rainy Wednesday night and the place is surprisingly pretty busy with a lot middle eastern locals in which I immediately think, "Oh this place is going to be good!".

We are seated right next to a large group at a small table while there's four open tables further away next to us so I ask if we can sit elsewhere. "Yeah, fine, sure. Sit where ever you want" as the hostess explained with attitude.

Okay...I'll always give the benefit of the doubt. We were seated at our table. Literally ten minutes goes by without even being acknowledged by the waitress even as she passed by us numerous times. We had yet to even receive a menu. However we didn't notice that our waitress did have time to stop at "a locals" table while speaking and flirting with a gentlemen for five minutes while speaking farsi. 

Eventually in disgust, I get up, walk to the front door and grab two menus myself. The girlfriend and I look over the menu, make our decisions, and put the menu down. The waitress continues to ignore us while passing us by numerous times. We wait ten more minutes without being acknowledged and I start to really loose my cool. I'm embarrassed at this point even in situations wear I pride myself on being calm, cool, and collected.

Eventually I have to grab what looks to be the owner and tell him we are ready to order. He says okay, speaks something in farsi to the waitress and she comes over to take our order. Keep in mind, there was no acknowledgement of any wrong doing or anything at this point. 

Fifteen minutes later (now almost 40 minutes into dinner) we get our food. The food is quite tasty although very dry without any sauces. At this point, I figured it would take another ten minutes to have them bring me any sauce so I refrain from asking.

I'm sorry but I can stand restaurants in this city that can't hire people who have basic customer services skills or a desire to provide good service. Obviously this is a family run restaurant and boy can you tell that they hire the 19 year old cousin to be the waitress. The whole atmosphere and level of service felt extremely weird. Almost a sense of "anti white" sentiment while blatantly ignoring my girlfriend and I throughout the meal and just an overall feeling of, "wow...this place is really amateur and doesn't have it together".

I'll never be back at this place for dinner in the restaurant. Take out? Maybe, but dinner inside the place, no way. Too many other good "mediterranean" places in this city that know how to deliver a good dining experience with real solid food.

My recommendation, pass on this place!!!
author: Jeff R.

description: Yemenis is amazing!  The food is excellent and the people are lovely.  I highly recommend.
author: Keri C.

description:
The waitress was very helpful and made suggestions. We enjoyed the yummy lamb and the kabsah rice seemed like it had raisins but it was just the sweet carmelized onions. The portions were huge and the bill average to low.

Two people with reasonable appetites could probably get by splitting an entree... that makes it one of the better deals in the hood.

Make sure to get the spicy sauce...unless you don't like cilantro.
author: Summer S.

description: The restaurant was dirty. Twice I order food to only be turned down by the waiter with a yellow smile saying "sorry we are our of that or this" until I had to say..."so what do you have?" At last they had a chicken plate that was horrible, dry, and burnt. Also, beware of the soup...it extra spicy and half cold.  The only thing I enjoyed was the bread...Do not go there it's a waste of money.
author: Tamer S.

description:
We got the kofta, the big crazy yemeni stone bowl (salteh), and some lamb. The crazy bowl thing was by far the best as the rest of our entrees were a little dry. The bowl thing was a tad too salty but if you're splitting it won't get too overpowering.

staff is super nice though!
author: Misha T.

description:
We were excited to eat here since the first and only time we ate Yemeni food was just across the street at Saha. And we really enjoyed it. So we put in a reservation via Yelp Open Table for a Friday evening.

Um don't really need reservation. It's really not a fancy place and not a lot of people. First impression was not good.. our table had yellow stain on it. And the lady owner maybe? grabbed one of our menus as it was handed over to us because she was taking an order over the phone. Not too professional. Most of the tables were set up for 4 or more people, which I found odd. Tables for 2 were pushed to the fringes like ours, by the kitchen.  

We ordered the La Sanaa Meza for appetizer which is like a sampler of many sauces like hummus and baba ghannouge, with falafel and tanour bread. I would recommend getting this as everything was delicious, esp the bread. They will bring you extra if you want. 

For entrees we went adventurous and ordered dishes we've never even heard of (but looked up on Google LOL). The Maqluba looked amazing on the pics we saw, so my partner ordered that. What we got was not at all what we saw.. it was just  grilled beef (or chicken if you want) over rice. For $14 not sure about the value so overall it was OK. The taste was good but like I said not at all like the pics. I had the Mandi Hadrami, which is baked ham served with rice. The lamb was super tender and good taste. I liked it but felt it was a little boring. 

We'll be back because we want to try the Salta and some other things. Service was good. It's not like Saha but it wasn't that bad. It's probably a family-run restaurant so some things are are not up to par but that's OK.
author: Vol T.

description:
If you know "middle eastern" food, this place is really not good. I had tried it for Iftar with a friend last year, and i really did not like it.. had a bad memory of it. This year my friend wanted to return for Iftar so i decided to give it another try - especially that they are under new ownership and now called Arabian Sky.

Food: I dont know Yemeni food.. but i know Jordanian, Palestinian, Lebanese, and food from the Maghreb. This "yemeni food" seems to be just a mix of anything deriving from any Arab country.. no specialty dish.  It serves Shak-Shoukah (Tunisian though made in different countries), Taboulleh, foul, hummus, baba ganoush, grape leaves, etc. 

*The hummus is the worst i have ever had anywhere.. i can make a better one FOR SURE. I think it was 3/4ths tahini (that they forgot in the baba ganoush lol) and 1/4th chickpeas. 

*The baba ganoush is not baba ganoush, its just crushed and cooked eggplant - i know there are different variations of this dish but i dont think there was even Tahini in it. 

*the grape leaves were really really bad. Again, they taste different based on who makes them usually (Turkish are always most flavorful) but these were canned and terrible.

*the Tabbouleh.. hmm.. i dont even know that it could be called Taboulleh. At least there was parsely.. but barely any tomatoes or bulgar/couscous

*The Lebneh was thicker than usual. It wasnt bad but it was not Lebneh as i know it.

*The bread was awesome

*The soup - my friend said was good, and it smelled good

*The "samosas" are not samosas.. though they are triangular. They were good but not typical "briques" at all. 

Service: Very sweet woman helping... but one woman for Iftar is not enough staff.. She can not bring dates and milk to everyone on time.. my friend ended up having no milk and other tables dipped their dates in water. We had to ask for bread.. ask for dates.. etc. Ask to order.. which of course didnt happen in time. 

*During Ramadan they have a buffet of soups, (one vegetarian included which is good), and fresh fruit salad (good).

Setting: ugly and depressing. Door was open and it was cold. 

-- I was sick all night.
author: Sara S.

description: The meat tastes so good it was melting like butter in my mouth. I love it and I am coming back here soon
author: Ahmed A.

description:
Stopped in on a rainy SF winter night craving a schwarma. Upon walk in I was greeted by the kindest staff! Offered home brewed tea as I await my order. ....btw the clove tea.. Amazing.  As several customers come and go, their attention to my (minimal) wait was never ignored. 

Seconds after I had finished the tea a server appeared with a fresh organic mango/strawberry drink that I must say, was the most extraordinary fruit beverage I have had in a long time!

I was given my dinner to go with a smile and it was returned with the same. 

I will return for the food as well as the experience!
author: Kat M.

description:
This is a great example of a fantastic restaurant disguised in a shabby, plain exterior.

While the exterior is unassuming and rather unpleasant, I was surprised to find a very comfortable and presentable seating area inside. The server was extremely gracious and gave us a homemade spicy soup on the house. Actually, she pronounces it "from the house" which is adorable. This is clearly a family business.

The food was plentiful. You'll get your filling of authentic Yemenese meat and spices. Aim for the specialty dishes (and desserts) and you'll explore presentations you never knew existed. The plates usually have a mixed portion of meat, rice, and veggies. That's always a plus in my book.

I will come here again .

-----

Distinguishing factor: A morsel of genuine Yemenese cooking that is served with utmost graciousness and generosity.
author: Nick A.

description: My husband and I get food from here a lot however today we were not pleased. We ordered the food to go like we usually do and had expected everything that we had ordered to be there but today it wasn't. We were charged for 5 bread but instead got 2 cold hard pieces. My husband and I have noticed that when a certain waitress is working the food is either cold, the order is messed up or she takes too long.
author: Rachel L.

description:
Great service, huge portions, friendly service, and great value. 

We started with the sampler which was just what you'd expect it to be; lots of choices, all vegetarian. For entrees, we tried both lamb dishes (under Yemeni traditional dishes) and they were both extremely tender and delicious (slight edge goes to the baked one). We finished with the fattah for dessert which was an excellent end to a meal that far exceeded expectations. Also, the tea they serve is very addictive, so don't be surprised when you find yourself on your fifth cup.
author: Alvaro H.

description:
Out of nowhere.

John O'Callaghan's epic track: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zsYjo2u-Lmc

Yemeni's epic chicken. Also out of nowhere.

Was seated first but my order was taken second. Not an auspicious beginning.

Then the chicken arrived.

Four or five pieces grilled and seasoned to perfection. So much flavor. I paused a few times to make a mental note this was some of the best chicken I'd ever had.

Served with a Northern Yemen basmati rice. Multi-colored and complements the meat well. Salad comes with it too. Generous. Dry.

Ordered a side of tanour bread. Made in house. Also made to go with all of the above for something truly special.

Server turned out to be quite sweet and attentive. ~$15 was more than reasonable.

Start was not strong. As good as it gets aka five stars by the end.
author: Jason B.

description: Food was delicious. Customer service was even better. Home style cooking and atmosphere. Friendly staff. Unique Yemeni cuisine. Definitely recommend, no hesitation!
author: Susan E.

description:
Great service.  Large savory portions at affordable prices.  I live in nob hill, so it's nice to eat out, but unfortunately a lot of places in the tenderloin aren't very cleanly.  Yemeni's was surprisingly brightly lit and well decorated.  

Excellent pita and humus.  Tasted so fresh--we stuffed our faces before our entrees could come, and had to take home leftovers (which is rare for us).  Loved the braised lamp and free sweetened tea!  Will definitely be coming back regularly.
author: Kelly S.

description: I had no food, so I can't comment on that. No one seated me / greeted me. I was ignored completely by whoever was supposed to be there. I walked to a table and everyone turned around. Not one person was a woman. All men! I quickly turned around and left. #wtf moment
author: Naomi A.

description: I took my hyper critical Lebanese father here and he loved it! I've never been to a middle eastern restaurant with him that he didn't have something to criticize. The food is very authentic and the chicken is amazing. Not to forget, very reasonably priced. If you're looking for some solid middle eastern food, this is the place to go. Get the #30 combo.
author: Jordan A.

description:
Hummus with nan was 5 stars.
Unfortunately, the rest room was trashed, enough to discourage me from going back.
author: Michael S.

description:
Masha'Allah (an Arabic phrase that expresses appreciation, joy, praise or thankfulness for an event or person that was just mentioned). The food here was DELICIOUS.The service was fantastic and the dishes came out quite quickly. We had the lamb and also chicken capsah. Both were delicious! We devoured the tasty goodness like a pack of ravenous wolves. 

Also be sure to try the house soup and house teas--both are remarkably unique, aromatic, and delicious!

 I'd been here long ago and wasn't nearly as impressed as my very recent visit. I think they may have changed ownership, because the place is head-and-heals better than what I remembered. Kudos to the owners for the changes!
author: Matthew J M.

description:
This place has amazing middle eastern food. Great breakfast ( beans, liver). 

The desert is awesome ! I had date fata. I would definitely be back. 

Your order might take a little longer but worth the wait.
author: Mohamed A.

description:
God (rather Allah) this place is so-four star it is sick! I've been friggin' trying to go to Yemen since 1996 when I first heard about this far corner of the Arabian peninsula. Travelers who have made it often told me that Yemen is one of the most friendly places they have ever been. Still, tales of war, abduction and civil unrest has kept most of the rest of us away. Not until now. Now we can actually visit a small slice of Yemen in our own Tenderloin backyard via a late afternoon trip to Yemini's.
Try the hummus and tea tea. Make sure and get the bread that is fresh out of the oven, resembles nan.
Try the Yemen soup, and ask if they have any authentic stuff not on the menu. I was treated to a feast of lamb, rice, and veggies one Friday evening that was served as part of a party after Friday prayers. Yummy in Yemini!
author: Brian J.

description: The place was right up the street from where I live. I love Middle Eastern Food and I love kebabs so had to try this place.  They are renovating outside the building so it didn't look very nice, but inside I was pleasantly surprised to see a nice and clean restaurant.  One thing that I would comment on was the server did not know the menu very well and they were not very accommodating when I asked if I could modify the order to have one ground lamb and one ground beef kabab instead of two ground beef kebabs. I ordered the kafta kebab and it was pretty good.  Flavorful and tender ground beef kebabs with rice and salad.  I ordered the yogurt which I usually dip the beef in, it needed more kick probably would have tasted better with a little more garlic or shallots.  Average priced in a good location.  Good place to go nice family run neighborhood restaurant. Had a good meal and was pretty happy!
author: Maria M.

description:
Impressive service and delicious food. Make sure to get the tea. Brandon and I used to eat at a Yemeni restaurant in Cairo, Egypt and this place was on par. Different spices, same dishes, all around a great spot for Arab cuisine. They even accommodated our specific request on certain dishes. 

Love it!
author: Savanna T.

description:
To gauge my tastes: Mediterranean food is my favorite cuisine. Ali Baba's Cave is a little too greasy-spoon and Palmyra's lacks fresh ingredients. However, both of my least favorite Mediterranean food spots are better than this.  

They served a watery/oily soup lacking in spices. Their yogurt was store bought and ONLY had cucumbers (no mint as promised from the menu). The chicken was burned and hardly spiced. The lamb (which my partner ordered) was mostly bones and overcooked. It came with a side of salsa that tasted suspiciously like the salsa Costco sells. The salad was made with iceberg lettuce and overripe tomatoes with a rancid-y tasting dressing. The lights in the restaurant (all of them) flicker.

The waitress was nice and was wearing a pleasant perfume. That was the only nice thing I have to say about my experience.

My girlfriend was so excited to leave, she had to stay the urge to bolt into the street. When we got home she said she was happy we were walking in the direction AWAY from Yemeni's.

For what you "could have" had prepared well there, you will find at Old Jerusalem. Huge portions, fresher ingredients and SPICES!
author: Josh O.

description:
We got food to go, which didn't take TOO long (maybe int he 15 minute range), and they have a little table where you can wait. So, no comments on the service (although the employees were pretty friendly) or presentation or anything - but the food was definitely still piping hot when we got home!

We tried the chicken schwarma wrap (also available as a plate), the fava beans, and a bread (they were out of the yemeni bread we wanted to try). The fava beans were flavored really nicely and made for a hearty dish, although it was entirely a sauce/dip of the beans - nothing on the side or anything else. The schwarma was fine - the bread was a little doughy and tough, but also pretty substantial. I have a feeling that particular dish doesn't really highlight the character of the place, and I'd try the "national stew" of salteh next time to capture that more.
author: Lisa K.

description:
They say the first impression can color your perpetual perception of someone (or something). Well, the hostess/waitress who took my take-out order seemed impatient with me as I inquired about the specials advertised outside, as well as how two dishes that sounded fairly similar differed from each other. Okay, fine: maybe this is a place that is not welcoming to newbies. That's understandable, I suppose. Having learned that the chicken version of the kasbah advertised on the specials board came with flat bread while the lamb version did not, I went with the chicken one. I was told there would be a 15-minute wait before my order would be ready, so I walked across the street to Jerusalem Market (which was awesome, by the way) to kill a few minutes.

After I returned, I sat in a little booth that faced the front of the restaurant and waited quietly for my order. Five minutes passed, and a dude who works there (maybe a waiter, maybe a kitchen staff member) came to me and asked if I had ordered the mandi hadhrami with lamb. Yes, in fact, I did. "Well, we're out of lamb." What, really? Um, okay. I really didn't want to order another chicken dish, which was the special I ordered. And the fish of the day (salmon) didn't sound interesting to me. After some stressful minutes with the menu and this guy I had a hard time understanding, the original hostess/waitress came by and said that my order was the last one they were packing up before they had to make a new batch of the lamb mandi hadhrami. Oh, okay, so really, I'm fine. Great!

As she later came out with my order, she even went back to it and double checked something while I was getting ready to pay. Despite the snafu, I tipped generously given that I thought I was going to get exactly what I ordered. Well, not quite. After I got home and unpacked everything, I realized that they forgot my flat bread, which I had really wanted to try. Argh, that was the only reason why I ordered the chicken kasbah instead of the lamb! At least everything else was there and tasted excellent.

The verdict: I probably won't be coming back anytime soon, but maybe I'll give them another chance later on when I've exhausted other options.
author: Tiff T.

description:
Got two entrees to go. Flavorful rice and big portions. I got chicken which was delicious. My brother had lamb and he loved it. Total was $28.

It seems to be family-owned, and they are very friendly.
author: Karen L.

description:
What is wrong with the hipsters downtown? This place is amazing and not very expensive, it should be overrun with your hunger for tastes far and wide! 

Hipsters, get thee to Yemeni's!

Recommend: Foul (fool) Medamas and the traditional clay pot Salteh with or without lamb.
author: alexander r.

description: Great, great kebab shop!  Glad we found it.  More authentic than the fusion and fake greek places in the area.  Service was great, reminded me of when we lived in Istanbul!  Hummus is the best in CA!  Kabobs were really good, if slightly overcooked, soup was delicious and tea finished off an excellent meal.  We will be back again.... and again... and...
author: Ben H.

description: One word: kabsah. Melt in your mouth goodness. Order it, you won't regret it. Both the chicken and beef are delicious. They also have really great tea at the front of the restaurant - remember to get some! I've been there more than five times and had great service every time. Highly recommended!
author: Christine F.

description:
So, to my understanding, Yemeni Restaurant has been open for about 4 months now. It had its initial struggles, as any new business does, but the improvements more than make up for the mistakes here and there that are part of the growing pains.

To those of you that have been in the Middle East, this is a real Middle Eastern restaurant, almost to the T. The owner, Ali, is a super friendly Yemeni immigrant that goes out of his way to ensure all of his guests (because you are guests, not just customers) are having a good time - and he will do what he can to make anything better. He also lovingly helps to prepare a lot of the food himself.

The waitresses are fine, decent, and friendly themselves, but be aware that all of the servers are rather 'green'. Don't be afraid to grab their attention. Be Middle Eastern! Be assertive (not aggressive), but kind and you will have a great experience.

That is really what Yemeni's Restaurant is - an experience. Sure, the decor isn't flashy and it could easily classify as a 'hole in the wall' restaurant atmosphere, but that's what makes it so great.

I've been there now at least a dozen times and have tried about everything on the menu. The menus, btw, have been updated to reflect the current menu choices and prices, although (as their website says), prices are subject to change.

This is truly a gem of a place in the Lower Nob Hill, and is well worth a visit. If you are going, please be aware that most Western palates are not used to the spices or techniques used - but for those who grew up eating this food, it is truly authentic and delicious.
author: Ariela R.

description:
Start of with the food which deserve 3 starts. Menu has good choices, and  multiple traditional options. 
Location is good with meter parking but should not be an issue. 
The service is OK, the owners provide good customer service but I held the 2 stars back because I received a lousy service from the young waitress. I called her twice for bread, she acted like she didn't hear me and when I asked for the check it took her 20 minutes to bring it back with attitude.  
Overall, I will be back hoping for the problem to be fixed.
author: Shadi K.

description: A hidden gem. For a great price I ordered La Sanna Meza for appetizer, stew & Kabsah which were all great.
author: Mister T.

description:
Any restaurant that cooks the bread fresh to order in house is a win in my book because you know they won't be taking shortcuts on the food!  The menu is full of hard to pronounce dishes that stray from the standard falafel and kabob choices.  Anything in a stew is probably awesome and a perfect excuse to use the bread!

Sahawiq Cheese: Ground up chilies, spices and cheese in a consistency somewhere between yogurt and cream cheese.  The dairy helps prevent it from being crazy hot.  A great dip alternative to the standard Middle Eastern choices.

Mandi Hadhrami: Basically slow cooked lamb shank with some stewed vegetables on rice.  The lamb was extremely tender with delicious melt away fat.  The veggies (celery, cauliflower, carrots, eggplant) were a bit soggy and bland.  The rice was long grained and quite fluffy.

Yemeni Salteh: You can't go to a Yemeni restaurant without having their national dish!  It comes out bubbling in a metal bowl like something you'd see at Korean tofu house.  The broth is a very thick and rich gravy topped with some egg foam and all sorts of spices.  Tastes amazing when you let some of the fresh bread soak up all the goodness.  I feel it's more about the broth base than the morsels of meat and veggies on the bottom.  HMM!

Grilled Kofta: Tiny little hockey pucks with a ton of flavor.  I like that it wasn't overly cooked with some nice pink hiding beneath the seared outer edge.  Much better spices in the minced lamb than a lot of those kabob houses around town.

Grilled Lamb: Thin pieces of lamb that still manage to have a nice medium rareness inside.  Very tasty spices on the charred outside.

Grilled Chicken: Dry and chewy.  Not their best grill offering.

Tanour Bread: Fresh out of the oven!  More like an over-sized puffy pita than naan.  So glad not to get those generic pre-made pitas from a bag.

Baklava: Well executed.
author: Adam B.

description: I was so happy to find a place in San Francisco that serves Yemeni food.  I ordered the saltah to go, along with malawah bread.  The order wasn't packaged properly for takeout and it spilled.  I wrote the owner and I was invited back for a replacement meal.  I can't wait to go back!  My meal looked and smelled so good, even though I couldn't actually eat it.  I look forward to updating my review once I actually get to taste it!
author: Eddie C.

description: I rarely give bad reviews but this place is just awful. Not one positive thing to say.
author: Kareem Y.

description:
Going for the first time was amazing. There wasn't many customers when I went so the service was somewhat on par. I think they only have 1-2 waiters working dinner shifts. The second time I went, the crowd was slightly heavier and they still only had 1-2 waiters working....didn't make sense. I'll make this review short and sweet.

Service
Slow and hard to make

Food
Starter
Don't remember name plate ($8)- you get 3 different types of dip (humus, a salsa-like dip, and an eggplant tasting dip); comes with a flat bread to dip. Perfect for 3-4 people. Good starter to share and have on the table (since you wait a while for the entrees.

Entree
BBQ Combo (~$12)- you get 3 types of meat (beef, lamb, and chicken- kabob style) Along with the meat assortment, you get rice, humus, and salad. The meat is quite tasty and tender. Good choice for your first time!

Side
Yumeni tea($2/person)- hot tea with a sweet twist


Overall, the food and great, but they simply need more waiters during peak hours. Not the best place to bring a date. More of a casual dining spot.
author: Derek L.

description: I had the best lamb of my life. If you are a lamb lover you should try lamb agda. The flavor was bursted with exotic spices and I fell in love with it
author: Marry M.

description: I really liked the food here. And the staff is very friendly. They gave us a lot of complementary deserts. I highly recommend this place for people who haven't tried the Yemeni food. People you must try the Fahsa.
author: Ali G.

description: Very hospitable and friendly staff. Food is delicious and very reasonable price. Whenever my parents visit we always come here. It's a great neighborhood restaurant to visit.
author: Hi Y.

description:
Yemeni's was a spontaneous, "let's see what's open on a Sunday morning" meal with my boyfriend. We just finished some apartment hunting, and were looking for something in the area to chow on. We went in without any Yelp recommendations so were simply choosing blind.

We thought this was generic Mediterranean food, but my ignorant, completely innocent mind thinks this was pretty authentic. We ordered:

moussaka
combo kebab plate
hummus and meat

The eggplant app was good! First time having it -- and the flatbread it came with was a perfect complement. The main dishes were just run of the mill for us. Nothing amazing -- and compared to a place in San Jose that we're fond of, not as good.

The service was not bad, but only because we were the ONLY customers in the restaurant. We got some free tea at the end which was sweet and refreshing. My sweet tooth bf loved it.

Next time, i'll definitely want to try their salteh since it's been so raved about on Yelp. Until then - three stars!
author: Alison C.

description: My wife and I recently had lunch at Yemeni's Restaurant (aka Arabian Sky). We shared the lamb and veggie Saltah and the lamb Haneed, both traditional Yemeni dishes. The lamb in each dish was falling-apart tender and moist. The Saltah is sort of a pulled lamb with veggie stew, and is scooped up with Yemeni bread. The Haneed was a braised lamb on the bone with lots of vegetables, served over rice. Both were very flavorful. I also had a Yemeni (hot) tea to drink, which reminded me of the local tea (chai) served in Turkey.  The restaurant was clean, the service was very friendly, polite and attentive (but not overly so), and the cost was very reasonable. The ultimate question: would we return? Absolutely!
author: Bill F.

description: My to-go place for lamb . Love middle eastern food and you get a bit of culture with the music videos. Oh and don't forget the complimentary soup.
author: Tri N.

description: Very good choice for yemeny resturante. I'll reccomend thier lamb mandi and lamb hanith. Any types of lamb they have is really good
author: Mohammad A.

description:
This place was a block from my hotel.  I got my order to go... so I can't comment on the wait service.  The lamb chops were AMAZING.  Seriously - ... awesome.  I met the owner, Mosa (totally adorable) - he was telling me they are recently opened (confused since they have so many reviews).  He threw in some bread and hummus/baba ganoush - which was also great.  The hummus had a slight mint taste - or something.  But it was great.  I wish they included more napkins    He told me to order the baked lamb next time - which I definitely will!  

Side note - they didn't have all their menu items.  I asked for cheesecake and was told the only dessert they had was baklava.  (not a fan generally).
author: Adam S.

description: Awesome. If you want people to look and speak exactly as you do, San Francisco is not the place for you
author: Harland K.

description: A friend of mine that has spent time in Yemen recommended this place. I'm so thankful she did. The salteh was one of the most delicious dishes I've had in ages. I shared that, along with the grilled lamb and tabouli. The bread is legit. If you don't know what to order, they've got you covered. It is all amazing. Get some of that sweet hot tea while you are at it.
author: Maureen S.

description:
It was great to have read these reviews before going to Yemeni's. I felt like I was back in Turkey (as close as I have been to Yemen, geographically and cuisine-wise). We were seated and disregarded the menus, instead asking the waitress what was available and what she recommended. We all listened and made our selections accordingly.

Dinner was tasty overall, but most of the meat dishes and the rice accompanying them was good but not amazing. However, the vegetarian "FOUL something" composed of Fava Beans was indeed AMAZING! Best flavors of the night. I would probably go back and just order a couple plates of that and bread and chow down.

For dessert the waitress said the owner's family had picked some fresh fruit over the weekend, and brought out a pretty fruit plate with honey drizzled on top. We had tea (loaded with sugar!) and ate our perfectly ripe fruit. The bill came and it was totally reasonable! (Gotta love being forced not to order alcohol - really brings the price of dinner down!). I'll be back for sure.
author: Jonah C.

description:
How is this place not flooded with Yelpers? 

The location is across from Saha which is not nearly as good. Yemeni's is authentic, fresh and delicious. No booze cause its Halal but well worth it and cheap too. The place can be pretty empty but you know its good cause there always cab drivers there. Cabbies always know the good spots.
author: E R.

description:
I would frequent this restaurant very often when I worked down the street. The staff there is very gracious and kind- and not in an unfamiliar sort of way, but in the warm way that you feel at home. 

The food has consistently been incredible. I nearly get a different thing every time I've gone, and thus far I haven't been dissatisfied. Plus the portions are insanely huge- definitely worth your money!
author: Daniel F.

description:
The food had flavor, though the portion of the kebab combo platter had a disproportionate amount of greens. 4 stars for bringing out the flavor and matching service.

(They make a wicked salsa type thing too- if spice is your thing)
author: Vivek N.

description: This place is incredible. The food is bomb, and the staff are the homies. They gave me hella free food to try and it was all hella good!
author: Roxanne C.

description:
I'd been to Yemen when I was young and kept remembering the cuisine and the way they cook lamb over there (delicious!), so when we found this restaurant reviewed here we jumped at the chance to try it. We also found out about Saha but I figured we'd give this restaurant a shot, and I hoped it was as authentic as it seemed.

We weren't disappointed. Though my diet these days doesn't include wheat and goes easy on carbs I was able to eat here without guilt - they also offer a vegetarian menu and solid veggie dishes. We got the lamb kabsah which was served with the ubiquitous Yemeni chili sauce zhoug, and not-as-traditional mezze platter and stuffed grape leaves, served with the traditional flatbread.

As soon as I tasted the lamb I knew this was the real deal. It was tender, moist and well-spiced, and the rice was excellent - the flavor of the food triggered many memories of when my family was invited to generous meals in Yemeni houses. We'll have to try the mandi and salteh next (and the lamb soup which tends to be a Yemeni staple), preferably when both my parents are in town. 

The owner is quite courteous as well, prices are extremely good for what you're getting, and the pictures are pretty much what you'd see in a true Yemeni restaurant. I'd complained often to the BF that a lot of restaurants purporting to serve authentic cuisine from Asia and the Mideast here seem to like to tone down their spiciness, perhaps to cater to a more Western crowd, but I was very happy to note that this restaurant has retained the flavor in its food. (To the owner, please don't pay attention to people who say the food is too spicy, they don't know what they're talking about.)
author: Kit A.

description: They have the best Chicken Swaerma & Rice in the city. They prepare to go orders very quickly and the new owners have done a nice light remodel. I'm so glad they got rid of the TV!
author: Star R.

description: I really liked the mandi there, it was very delicious!! And Mart was very helpful and friendly. Thank you!
author: SmoOkey A.

description: After years of flying through the Middle East, I finally suggested to my wife that we try the food and asked American Express for a restaurant recommendation.  This was one of the choices they offered us.  One of us ordered the chicken Shwarma, the other, lamb, shared the dishes and found the food very good.  We tried the lentil soup, the vegetable salta, grape leaves -- all very gpod.
author: Thomas H.

description:
Wednesday, 9:30PM.

Quickie:
*Decent food
*Lighting is dull
+Nice service
+Spacious

And then...?
Dishes are lacking some flavor firepower. The folks are nice though, so I'll give it one more go next time.

*********
Stuffed my face in:
1. Falafel
     - Dry middle: the dab of sauce on each piece was not enough to battle the arid 
     nature of this grounded garbanzo
author: Chuck N.

description:
I went with a large group (about 15) and they were super accommodating.  Separate checks for everyone, free hot tea after dinner, and even complimentary dessert (which was a crazy good something with nuts, honey, bananas, etc.).

I had something with lamb (I think called Hadeen?) and it was delicious.  Great food and good service, will go back for sure!
author: Woody M.

description: Large family dinner - 15 people - 2 nights in a row!  Great food and service!
author: Sharona S.

description: The first clue as to how good the food would be was the restaurant was filled with Yemeni patrons. We were a group of six and sat at a round table perfect for the family style platter piled with succulent lamb, an excellently spiced roasted chicken, some delicious boneless chicken, wonderfully seasoned long grain rice with vegetables. This after a sumptuous lamb soup, Yemeni bread, humus, baba ganoush and yogurt platter and some really excellent felafel. The dessert was a warm banana creation which... even though we were critically full... was too good to miss. The very charming proprietor, Musa, has just taken over and he helped us order. The food is extraordinary even in our city of extraordinary food. The whole experience was delightful.
author: Micki E.

description: Honestly, one of the best Arabic meals I had in the states!! I had the kabsa and I was spectacle about it but it was to die for!!! Good too over all but such bad service honestly. We spent an hour after we finished eating till someone came and took our card and processed everything. You just have to keep on asking for people to come and serve you instead of being served.
author: Fatimah A.

description:
I use to come to this place weekly several years ago but other than the fact it's the only genuine middle eastern place around there that's the only reason why I went there.

what I noticed is that they cut down on the size of the kabobs and the soups are very salty.
author: N A.

description: Great place to eat at. We ordered fahsah, foul, shakshookah and  akdah. The desert is really delicious, it was fattah with banana and honey. Overall, the food is cook in a very traditional Yemeni style.
author: Ghadir B.

description: This has to be the worse restaurant experience I've had in decades, perhaps in my life.  I've enjoyed different cultural and ethnic food experiences with happiness but this may have taken me off of Middle Eastern food forever.  My party ordered 4 different menu items and not one was edible.  The couscous was ok but bland.  I has a dish with beef that consisted of a bone that I wouldn't give to my dog. No meat at all.  Chicken and lamb entrees were equally bad. Four chances for a decent meal and four failures. The staff were nice but unfortunately the unseen cook was incompetent.  I can't believe the favorable reviews on this disaster.  The only explanation is that there might be a cook that works only certain nights who knows what he's doing.  My advice is to not to take a chance on finding him at work.  There are certainly far better places to eat.
author: Bill J.

description:
New favorite spot in the TenderNob!  Inexpensive and lots of vegetarian options.  I especially like the appetizer sampler, for $9.95 you get hummus, baba ganouj, tabbouleh, garlicky yogurt, and moussaka, plus bread.  Hummus on its own is $4-5.  

Negative is that with hummus and other appetizers, you have to order the bread separately.  But at $1.95 a piece, it's not a bad thing.
author: Sona P.

description: The waiters need to dress up and put your pants up or a belt you keep pulling you pants every time when you walk by !!!! And place service the people that come first not because they are arbs and you know them!!!!!! Yaqoop we was here before you friends so please keep your friends out of your job hours or invite them to you house!!!!!! We have be waiting for hour to get the food and when arrived it was cold !!!!
author: MoNa O.

description: Awesome!! Highly recommend!! I stopped into Yemeni's 1-11-15 to get some dinner after a long exhausting day in SF. Yemeni waited on me personally and not only gave exemplary customer service but also made me feel like I was dining at a friend's house. I had the Shish Kabab sandwich which was delicious- the chicken was tender, cooked perfectly and the mixture of spices were very tasty. Thanks Yemeni- one of my favorite meals during me trip to CA! -Lori
author: Lori O.

description: Uncooked chicken. Awful. They served us RAW chicken. They were sorry when we sent it back but that doesn't cancel the fact that we put raw chicken in our mouth.
author: Ludo G.

description: We went there for a quick dinner before a movie. The server was courteous, quick and considerate. We ordered 2 appetizers and a salad, to which our server recommended to order the appetizer platter that has a sample of all of them and more. The falafel was amazing. The main dish was also delicious. I recommend this restaurant. We'll go back for sure. One thing to know is that their in-house beverages are very sweet. I got a cup of their tea. It was way too sweet for my taste. I could hardly down it.
author: Alfred L.

description: Everything I've had here is fabulous! The hummus and thin breads are amazing to start, and the Fahsah is absolutely incredible! Musa is so incredibly friendly and welcoming, and the tea is so tasty and sweet. I encourage everyone to come here and check this amazing place out!
author: Alexxis J.

description:
Mixed food experience but got a seat really easily and the other guests did seem to be regulars.

Went on a Sunday afternoon and it was nearly empty. The appetizer of baba ganoush was quite good. Shared an entree of lamb and it was pretty flavorless. Overall, decent dining experience and fun to try a new cuisine but probably won't be heading back unless I'm in the area
author: Ojus P.

description: It was our last night in S.F. and our friends who live there recommended it.  The food was excellent.  My wife did not have a large selection because she is allergic to corn and all of it's by-products but she loved what she had.  I had a salmon special that I loved.  They let us stay chatting for a long time and I left my ball cap there.  Hopefully they will send it to me.
author: Jim W.

description: I've been here 3 times. The first time was several years ago and it was a bit of a let down. I decided to try it again about a month ago and loved it so I came back again and it was great both times. I think it's a family run business. They are very nice and checked on us multiple times to make sure everything was going well. The food was great and has an authentic homemade feel. Prices are extremely reasonable and portions are large. I recommend the baked lamb
author: Mohammad S.

description: I was fortunate to have been staying at the Hotel Carlton which is just right across for this restaurant. It's walking distance to a variety restaurants, this being one. Ordered for pick up and got the appetizer sampler and that was really good. My bf got the beef shawarma and I got beef kebabs. Both were good but the meat was a tad dry which was a bummer.
author: Maria G.

description: The food was great but the service, at least on the night we were there, was poor. The staff wasn't friendly and the food took forever. They did apologize and gave us our drinks for free, which I did appreciate. There were families with screaming kids that made it kind of annoying and I think they were friends of the staff. We ordered the beef kabsah (great, tender beef), Chicken Magluba (delicious with a few nice spicy chilis) and veggie kabob (tasty but not as good as the meat dishes). I'll go back and upgrade to 4 stars if we get better service.
author: Tom F.

description:
The first time I saw their menu and read the description of the Salteh which is 'served volcano style,' I was hooked. Salteh is an intense, wonderful lamb stew that, as advertised, comes out in a crazy stone bowl that is approximately the same temperature as the surface of the sun. I don't know a thing about Yemeni food, but this dish must be one of the signature national dishes, as it's quite unlike anything else I've ever devoured. So good!

Their other food is good, too, but not as wild as the Salteh. The only thing I wasn't impressed with were the dolmades. They were rather dull, in my opinion.
author: Todd H.

description: Great service. Food was really good. Great quality. The saltha was spicy and enough to share between 2 people. The highlight by far is their bread.
author: Justin M.

description: The food is great but I'm sorry to say that their customer service really sucks especially when I order over the phone . Work on that please .
author: Aiman T.

description: We decided to give this place a try under the new management since our last 2 visits under the old management were not great experiences. We were still disappointed. The service is extremely slow and non existent and the food leaves much to be desired. The Yemeni lamb dishes are better than the shawarma and kebabs but nothing is great. After 4 visits I think we will stay away from here.
author: Faiz S.

description:
rice was really good
lamb was good
Im not used to the beef though
author: Diane W.

description: Amazing restaurant, fresh food, halal which is considered to be very delicious. I literally love to eat there!!
author: Husam A.

description: Got the kabsah with chicken which was good but very very oily. They give a large amount of food. For generous portions and friendly hostess and a large dining room they get lots of pluses. Would have loved to try some more but was only visiting and the oil left a bad impression.
author: Sumaia I.

description: Good food.  Service could have been better. Meat and rice were not as soft as it was supposed to be. Overall , nice place to eat. Consider the crowded parking around the restaurant.
author: Syed F.

description:
This is a great place to go if you like restaurants run by two giggling 12-year-olds. I went there for dinner. It took about eight minutes after we were seated for them to realize that maybe we needed water. I asked the tittering preteen in charge for a vegetarian menu as they had one on display outside. My dinner date had to get up and ask the other girl for it about 12 minutes later. After an additional ten minutes of my death stare, it occurred to them to take our orders.

The food was mediocre. We had fatoosh, "grape leaves" (dolmas), and falafel wraps. I'm not a falafel snob, but the falafel in the mall is way better. 

I felt a bit sorry for the table next to us. She was allergic to garlic, and he was trying to find out what dishes could be made without garlic. The server didn't seem to understand or accommodate. Then the guy sitting alone at the table next to them started barking about how they could just order the cheese and olive plate and some bread and "make a meal out of that." I thought that was pretty rude; having my own dietary restrictions, it's totally lame to have to settle on, like, a salad made only of iceberg lettuce at a restaurant, where they seemingly would be able to cook something to order. Plus, a garlic allergy is, to me, a fate worse than death.

That guy acted like he knew the "working" girls but wasn't really concerned with whether they were working, which they weren't unless you count snickering behind a screen and squealing about texts they were receiving and sending.

We waited 20 minutes or so for our check; my icy glare did nothing but exhaust my eyes. At least they gave us mints.

UPON MY RETURN: There ain't gonna be one, suckas.
author: Sarah S.

description: Ate dinner here just now. Good not great. I had the shawarma which was well seasoned but a little dry. Rice had little flavor. Salad was light and refreshing. I was also a bit destructed by the pigeon that had gotten in that none of the employees seemed interested in shooing. Probably won't come back.
author: Rebecca H.

description:
The woman at the register (owner I believe) is so sweet and the people there seem very nice.    

I ordered lentil soup and falafel for take out.  The falafel lacked flavor and was extremely dense and dry.  None of those things are how I like my falafel.  I couldn't bring myself to finish it.  I'm sorry to say this, but it was some of the worst I have tried - including pre-packaged, so if you're thinking about ordering it, think twice.  

The lentil soup also lacked flavor, and although it was eatable I would not order it again.
author: N A.

description:
This is place is very low-key and it's truly a hidden gem in the upper tenderloin. How many restaurants do you know that don't serve alcohol?  
As soon as you walk in, you will find yourself in a very quite, intimate setting. The interior is mismatched, as there seem to be random items hung on walls, which makes it all the more charming. The place doesn't try to attract any attention or even make it look like it's open, but it serves fantastic food in very generous portions. When you go, you must order their tea- likely the best tea I have ever tried. Make sure to try their fish dish. It might be the biggest fish entree you have ever had (and probably the best). The prices are surprisingly reasonable - maybe even too reasonable for what you get. How many restaurants downtown do you know where you can have 4 people stuffed with great food for $60?   

The waiters could be a little friendlier, but hey - this just adds to the middle eastern edge of the restaurant.   

I have been there 3 times in the past two weeks and will likely be back soon.
author: Arkady I.

description:
I work across the street from this restaurant and a couple of the team members have said that this was a great restaurant for a lunch break, so we decided to give it a try!

The food is absolutely delicious and so fresh! Their La Sanaa Maza Appetizer is absolutely wonderful!! the Tanour Bread comes out fresh baked and warm. The hummus, tabbuleh, falafel and grape leaves are great as well. The service itself is s little bit slower than I would like, however, is decent enough that it is well worth the wait for the quality of food!

We go there atleast once a week now it seems and are pleased everytime!
author: Jamie Y.

description: I will always pick this place when I want a combo plate. Appetizer combo - Yum
author: Jsphn T.

description: This food is delicious & savory. I attended an event catered by Yemeni's Restaurant & the food was great!
author: Lily R.

description:
why did I forget to write a review about this place?
these are as much for my own reference as it for others and looking back I wish I had written down my impressions.  Luckily for me, my friends are more diligent about reviewing places.

The Fattoush appetizer was good, big and best shared.
The Chicken Kabob was good -- generic (not in a bad way at all)
The Lamb was on the dry side

I ordered the Salteh (Yemeni National Dish)
it was really really good.  It had awesome spices that I couldn't identify other than just it being tasty.

it's not fancy nor is it divey
it's a very good deal for the price =)

I plan to go back!
author: Van W.

description: The shawarma and honey drizzled flatbread are insanely good, so good I went into a coma because I couldn't handle the rich flavors drop kicking my taste buds. If it wasn't for The Avengers, I would never have found the power of shawarma.
author: Aaron B.

description:
I went into this place due to it being new and also cause I was pretty bored with everywhere else in the neighborhood. The first time I ate here I was sold. Really good food, good(non blitzed) atmosphere, and super friendly and good service. I think I have had almost everything on the menu now, and have yet to be disappointed. The lentil soup/tanour bread combo is a must every time. I definitely recommend checking this place out, the food is great!

Oh yea, and the prices are super good too!
author: Billy T.

description: Super legit.  I am on a middle eastern food kick.  I drove by and decided to try it.  My husband and I were probably the only people in there that didn't speak Arabic - no joke.  The hummus was THE BEST I HAVE EVER HAD. Better than A la Turca, better than Oren's Hummus in Palo Alto which I adore, better than Mezes, etc. The entrees are large sized and delicious.  Yum.  I will be going back.
author: Deal G.

description: The worst slowest service I have ever experienced in my life. I have never seen a restaurant operate that way. There is no one on the floor servicing people! Servers just come out once in a while but there is never really any staff on the Floor. Their soup/ stew w/ meat ( forgot the dish name ) and you eat it wirh naan was just ok. Maybe im not used to the flavor. Their combo meat dish is very good. Comes with sole yellow rice. Good portion.
author: Carrie T.

description: I loved this place/ wonderful taste/ dont forget to try their free tea it is amazing/ I ordered Mandi Plate also Lamb ribs both were great.
author: Ramy A.

description: Their food was super delicious. The best middle eastern i've had in a long time, and i've been to several middle eastern counties. We started off with the mar'a soup, and the mixed appetizer which is falafel, hummus, labneh, baba ganoush, tabuleh salad and fresh baked bread. Then for the main dish my husband and I ordered i think it was called handeel or hadim, which is lamb in a little tomatoe sauce just for flavor on a bed of nicely flavored rice and salad. And then finished off with some tea. Their portions were very big. I took most of it home, but an hour later I was craving some more and was able to finish it off. Their food had all the right flavors and not too spicy hot. Their service was excellent, our waitress was very polite. Next time we go to San Francisco this place is on our list for sure.
author: A A.

description: Really good food, very welcoming people work there. Had a pleasant experience.
author: CatsPjs Z.

description:
Me and bf went there at 4:20pm and get out at 5:50pm. We spent 20mins to eat our food so over a hour was spent on just to take our order and cook it. Really slow cooking. All our dish was really salty. Lentil soup wasn't cooked well plus too much black pepper in it. Side order veggie stew was okay but needs more spices. Roasted lamb dish lamb came in tomato sauce...? Combination dish chicken lamb kefta meat was so freakin tough and dry chewy salty 2 small flat pieces each. I'm complaining because my bf is middle eastern and also his a chief. So I know how it suppose to be or way it should be. 
But I liked their clay pot dish. It says soup with lamb and veggies on their menu but came out really soft lamb pieces with few celery pieces with soup in clay pot. There was a bread on bottom of the pot so dried out all my soup. However I liked it. I've noticed that they give complimentary soup first but we didn't get one. 
Also waitress girl was really rude.
author: Namuna B.

description: I was hesitate to try this place but I'm glad I did.  Everything tastes better then I expected and the customer service was friendly.
author: M S.

description:
AMAZING food. Really low-key and hidden. Gone here for dinner so many times. Take visitors here often too. All the meat here is so moist and tender and flavourful. I continue to return as it isn't overly expensive and the woman who works here knows so much about all the dishes and completes the Yemeni excursion. 

Salteh, mandi, mothabi... can't go wrong. Get lamb.
author: Dilip R.

description:
So, my new goal, food-wise, is to eat at more place that slightly intimidate me. This restaurant intrigued me for a long time, as I frequently drive past it. For some silly reason, I thought that I might feel out of place there or not understand the menu, but I got over that. I went there with 4 friends, one of whom spent time in the middle east and was able to offer some explanations of different food. I'm sure the servers could have done that, too, obviously... who, by the way, are most likely the teenage daughters of the owner & were very sweet. 

We were pretty much the only people in the whole place (we were definitely the only white people). A couple of guys came in as we were leaving. I ordered the "Foul Wrap" (pronounced 'fool') which was spiced fava beans in a buttery flat bread - REALLY GOOD and only $6.95!!! The prices here are great. I also had the sahadiq (sp?), which was a very spicy feta cheese dip. Our table also ordered shawarma and a few other appetizers, and many side orders of the delicious flat bread - i forget what it is called. Everyone was satisfied.

It is halal and pretty much the only drink options are sodas. The owner came out and said hi to us, it is that kind of chill place where they have the time to do that. I bet the Yemeni community in SF has a lot of parties and special events here and thats how they manage to stay in business. Well, I found out that I really love fava beans from my dining experience here - definitely a good & useful discovery!!
author: Shannon R.

description:
So this Middle Eastern man who visits the place where I work always goes to this restaurant when he is in town..I look it up on Yelp and saw my Yelp buddy also has been here and gave it a great review..I have to try it! 

Yelp friend and I with 3 other people came after a night of drinking. The service was great the ladies were very friendly. We ordered the Meza platter that disappeared into our tummy within 5 minutes, no joke it was that good! We all wanted number 30 on the menu, it was rice, tomato lettuce cucumber salad and meat! Chicken, beef, pork. We ordered 3 orders of that and had them put it on a large platter for all of us to share. It was a delicious family feast! The only thing I wasn't a huge fan of was the beef kebab, it had some spices I wasn't a fan of. We ordered a side of yogurt sauce(MUST GET) to dip our tasty meat in. To end the night we had this HEAVENLY dessert. Holy crappers! I love bread pudding..I don't remember the name of this but it was like french toast bread pudding it was amazing!! It had a crunch from the caramelized outside, nuts, dates, bananas, honey, yogurt sauce, moist. I am making myself drool right now. I was seriously in heaven I wanted to KISS the Chef! Yes that good!  For that dessert I give 5 stars.
author: Karen T.

description:
Arrived in San Francisco after a late flight and had few choices in the neighborhood that were affordable, unique, and not a bar.
