What a find! The restaurant is on the corner of a moderately quiet area. It was a little closed off in terms of windows, but when we entered, the atmosphere was quiet, heavily spiced, and comfortable.

We had the soup, shared an entree (lamb, I think), and ordered the bread which was amazing.

We've returned to feast on more soup, bread, and appetizers since our first meal.

Overall a great deal in the midst of all that SF has to offer!
author: Elena A.

description: The food was so delicious and comes in big portions, the hospitality and service were outstanding. I am from Florida and I will defiantly come here again.
author: Mohammad S.

description:
Food is good. Dishes are wanderful. Do u know why I rated it for one star? Because the service is very very slow. We spent 20 min till some one pick up our order!!!! Another 15 min to get our order. There is no enough and sufficient crew. These lead to have several confusions in the plates such as telling them to exclude banana but they did exclude dates!!!! When u got ur orders on the table forget forget that they will answer you immediately if u ask for bread or hot souce or whatever. When you want to pay even at cashier you need to wait. Come on san fransico there is no one to work and serve clints in this restaurant 

Sorry yelp viewers there no zero star the minimum is one
author: T B.

description: I was really pleasantly surprised by their food- the foul wrap was amazing!
author: Ali B.

description: I love this place the food is awesome i tried the mendi , combo chicken and kofta, trout everything was soo good, i love the manager (Sana) she's so sweet and lovely her service was awesome very good hospitality.
author: Suzan A.

description: Great food very authentic the rice is amazing the lamb is delicious, service is awesome
author: Dean W.

description:
We wanted to like this place, and while it wasn't terrible, it wasn't very good. Went for dinner -- restaurant was about a quarter full. Our waitress appeared to be around 16 years old, shy, inexperienced and poorly trained. She initially brought water and one menu, although we were three people. After we ordered she did not take the menus away. When our meza platter arrived, she forgot the bread. And so on it went. Meza were good (especially the warm dolmas) but rest of meal was average -- a Yemeni chicken and rice dish was bland, with a few small pieces of chicken still sporting rubbery, flabby skin and otherwise mostly rice. Koftas were slightly burnt, overly compacted and dry.  A Yemeni salad was fine.

There was sporadic running around visible in the doorway leading to the kitchen, and an overall sense of confusion and amateurishness that would have been forgivable had the food been memorable -- alas, on our visit, it wasn't. Perhaps we hit Yemeni's on an off night.
author: J. P.

description: Delicious food, and spectacularly friendly service. I'm still dreaming about their rice and their tea... yum!
author: Celina T.

description: What a great find in the cathedral hill - nob hill area ... I ordered a schwarma special to go along with baba ganouche (spelling?) and they graciously prepared the order quickly.  If the take-out is any evidence, the food generally is delicious.  Even when consumed after a short walk home, the food was moist, well-seasoned, tender.  The quantity of food was abundant ... in a town where price doesn't correlate with quantity (or quality!), it was a pleasure to get both quantity and quality.
author: Vince V.

description: I really enjoyed the Falafel, Humus ,Lamb,pita,chicken & ground beef kabob it was the best I ever had! Our waitress was attentive & very nice. I wasn't very excited over the salad it was pretty plain. I like the place & food I will return!
author: Sparky W.

description:
this restaurant is now named something else like Nights of Arabia (change in management?) or something like that
the large Saltah Lamb and Veggie (served in a boiling hot pot) was very very  good but I don't think it came with anything (or they forgot to give us anything to go with it) but luckily we also got the chicken "shish taouk" which came with a very generous amount of rice and salad and that mixed well with the Saltah. that fed two of us nicely and was "almost" grain free except the rice part  :)
my friend got the chicken rice dish kabsa with chicken and he said it kinda reminded him of fried rice (but he said he would def come back and get it again). We liked the chicken shish taouk - the chicken was tender and nicely flavored. the service was meh but if you're like me and love good quality great priced cuisine and don't care about the waiter service that much -then this is the place to go. we are definitely coming back (just don't come if you're in a hurry unless you get a to-go order).
author: Win H.

description:
Part 1.5 of $200 date day. 

We were an hour early from our next appointment, so we used the Yelp app on our phone to find a $ restaurant. Yemini was right next to our next appointment, and it was only 1 $. Perfect! 

The restaurant is huge, and looked like it used to be an old Chinese restaurant. The waitress was really nice, even though we didn't know what Yemin was, and did not know anything about their food or culture. We ordered the Taboleh (I think that's how it's spelled), Salta, this Yemin national dish, which was a sizzling stew in a clay pot, and an order of falafels. When we asked if they served alcohol, they did not, so we asked if we could bring some in. The waitress said it would be ok, so hubby ran out to the liquor store. While he was gone, the waitress moved me to the back of the restaurant, explaining that she did not want to offend anybody coming back from prayers. It turns out they're Muslim (I think), which means no alchi. :( 

The food was amazing. I've never had Yemin food before, but it seemed similar to Indian food, but not as salty. They used natural spices, instead of salt. The stew came out sizzling, and the meat inside was so tender. The falafels were crispy, and we were told they were made fresh daily. The bread they used to dip was just OK. Even fresh out of the oven, the texture was a bit tough for me. 

This was a nice, unplanned surprise in our date day, setting me back $20, with $130 left to go.
author: Vi Y.

description: I ordered take-out from this place and they did not give me what was in the description of the meal. Specifically a side of bread was left off and instead of giving any baba ganoush they replaced it with an excessive amount of tzatziki sauce. In a previous meal that I ate at the restaurant, the vegetarian dish consisted of burnt vegetables and rice. Overall, the place is not great and is a last resort when I have a hankering for falafel.
author: David P.

description:
Had the kufta plate (lamb meatball/puck), hummus, and their fresh tanour bread.

The kufta was flavorful and moist.  The outside had a nice grilled crust with plenty of spices

The hummus was not the best, but it ranks up there with the better places.

The tanour is freshly baked and a good 8"-9" in diameter.

A lot of their dishes are well under $10 and but you can always share th
author: Jason K.

description:
Went over on saturday with my wife. I really liked  it.  Very tasty and different from what I've had in the past.

We had the lamb soup, grape leaves for the entree. On the hosts (looked the owner's wife ?) recommendation, I had the roasted lamb (haneed). It was very tender and flavorful. Together with the rice, it tasted the good even though there was no gravy. Wife had the shish kefta. It all looked like standard Middle Eastern dishes but the taste was different and really good.

For dessert, we had fattah with date & banana, again on the recommendation of the host. This was a new type of dessert for me  and it really tasted awesome. 
Note we took it home since we couldn't finish the whole thing and once cold, reheating it didn't bring back the same taste. It needs to be had fresh.

The hosts (owner and his wife) were a friendly lot, stopping by several times enquiring about the meal and answering our questions.

Decor was nice. needles to say, we will be back when we visit the city with the kids.
author: Waseem S.

description:
While heading to Mediterranee in Fillmore for some fine Middle-Eastern food,  our attention was caught by this restaurant and we jumped out of the bus ready to test it. The place is family owned and the staff is truly accommodating.  

What about the food? Meza (tabbouleh, hummus, yoghurt with cucumber, mosaka,baba ganoush) are great! Only remark,  if you don't like cucumber (I belong to the category), you can have a hard time with their version of  tabbouleh. My gf's vegetable Salteh (Yemeni's national dish) was rich, spicy  and different from anything I had tried before. My slowly cooked and spiced lamb was flavourful and wonderfully tender.  The two different kind of flat bread we tried were truly awesome.  The dessert, a Moroccan style pastry (with the usual pistachios, orange flower syrup etc.), was  good but a bit ordinary. 

Seriously good contender for the title of best Middle Eastern restaurants in the city.
author: Andrea L.

description:
Basically, come for the great food, but not the service. The food is some of the best Middle Eastern food I've had in San Francisco, but I received some of the worst service possible in this restaurant. The two male servers are very nice but the waitress I encountered was very very rude. They just opened up so the service is sub par, but the rudeness is just unnacceptable. I would advise you to speak to the two male servers because they are very friendly. Also, the prices they print on the menu are not correct, so if you do come here, ask for the price for everything you order before ordering them. Apparently it takes too much effort to print out a new menu.

First of all, they served us the main dish first, then the appetizer, then our drinks. Shouldn't it be the other way around? When we ordered an additional dish, they forgot to cook it for us. When they realized this, they told us they did not have this dish, the Tandoori chicken, but had a similar dish, the Grilled Chicken. I asked if the price was the same and the waiter said yes. When we asked for the bill, they billed us $9 instead of $4 for the grilled chicken. When I told them that they said the dish was $4, the waitress went away and raised her voice and said to the other person she was working with, "I tell everyone that the prices in the menu are wrong! They want to pay $4 for a huge dish, this dish is clearly not $4!"

This is very unprofessional behavior because all the other customers in the restaurant could hear her complaints, including me. She did not even mention to me that the prices in the menu are different until after I ate the dishes. Be wary that what you order may not be what you pay for, because they are too lazy to even correct their menu or tell customers that the prices are changed.
author: Corabel S.

description: My friend had a birthday party over there. The food was good and reasonable priced. Additionally, I got to the party late and the rest of the party ordered. I was appreciative that when I got there, the wait staff asked the chef to rush my order so that I could eat with the group.
author: Manisha C.

description: It is a great restaurant ... I ate Mandi with lamb I recommended it highly I will go back there definitely.
author: Al Muhannad A.

description: This place was delicious. We went for a family meal on a Saturday night and they were so hospitable and friendly. Every dish that came out was super fresh and hot with bold flavors and beautiful presentation. The Haneed (lamb shank) was very well cooked and falling off the bone. The Shish Taouk was brilliantly spiced and went so well with the flavorful rice and freshly cooked flat breads. Definitely coming back here!
author: Marina M.

description:
When was the last time you ventured to the Tendernob?  
Have you ever had Yemenese food?
Does it matter that their website is "under processing" [sic] at www.yemenirestaurant.com?

This place is a wonderful addition to the community.  The Middle Eastern cuisine delights... naan, shawarma, hummus, tabouleh.  yum!  The owner eats his own cooking and will be there when you are there... he might even seat you and take your order.  Don't miss out on the chance to chat him up and request a few recommendations.

I will be back!
author: Kevin F.

description: I really like this restaurant and I highly recommend it to everyone. They are so friendly and nice. The taste was awesome and arabic taste. Honestly, if I have chance to go there I won't hesitate.
author: Yaz M.

description:
I received a tip about this place from a Yemeni taxi driver en route to the airport and had been meaning to go ever since.  I finally made it last night.  The restaurant is very mellow and the food is delicious.  I will definitely be back.

We ordered grilled lamb and the fish, both of which were yummy.  Plates are big and come with rice and salad.  The waitress said the fish was a whole sea bass but I'm convinced it was actually trout.  But what the hell, it  was amazing.  The black sweetened Yemeni tea was a perfect accompaniment to the meal.  There is no alcohol here and they don't want you to bring any in either (we asked for future reference).  To accompany our meal we ordered a feta cheese dip with Yemeni spices, which was amazing and had a nice spicy kick, and hummus, the only thing I probably would not order again.  I'm sure the hummus was good by Yemeni standards, but I found it to have too much of a tahini flavor and not enough salt, which is simply not what I'm used to and found I don't prefer it.  For dessert we had a flaky yemeni bread with butter and honey that was a perfect finish to the meal.

This place is quite inexpensive for what you get and will definitely be on my list of go to places for a healthy, inexpensive meal.

Enjoy!
author: Fred S.

description:
Authentic, cozy, and CHEAP! What's not to enjoy? The menu has a lot to offer, but admittedly needs to be reorganized and marked with translations for easier ordering.

Take a look at the appetizers and try the likes of hummus, fresh babaganoush, thick yogurt cucumber spread, lentil soup, and grape leaves served warmed.

The entree list does not disappoint with tons of options and flexible substitutions. They noted a soon-to-be seen menu update which sounds exciting. Service was pleasant, but a bit slow considering there were only 3 tables occupied. Inexpensive good food, in the heart of San Fran.... love it!
author: Theresa T.

description: So I can't comment on how authenticly Yemeni the food is, but I can say it was delicious.  We ordered both types of bread (Tanour and Malawah) and both were hot and fresh from the oven.  The hummus was light and tasty and the Baba Ghannouge had a smokey flavor that was perfect.  We tried both lamb dishes and both came out with large portions and piping hot.  At this point we were both happily stuffed and had no room left but we couldn't leave with out trying the Fattah dessert.  It didn't disappoint.  Not overly sweet and covered in a barely sweetend yemeni style cream that was unlike anything we'd had before.  We left with a huge portion of leftovers and the bill for 2 of us was $42.  Lastly, the service was a delight.  We will definitely go back to try more of the menu.
author: W D.

description: Fresh ingredients. Good value. Yemen cuisine. No alcohol.
author: Chris L.

description:
Had a delicious lunch at 12:00ish.  The food was outstanding and the service was equally impressive.  Our server explained dishes to us and offered a warm smile.
We started off with hummus(could have used some salt) and olives with bread all for about $6 and we ate every last bit.
We shared Yemeni Salteh(Lamb & veggies stew)  with bread and meat $$8.95 which was tasty with a mild spice.
I consumed most of the Mandi Hadhrami $8.95 which is lamb seasoned overnight and then roasted (5 stars) served with rice and some of the most delicious carrots I have ever enjoyed.
Ended the meal with Yemeni coffee $1.95 which has cardamom.
author: Robert G.

description: I have been here four times and only ordered the bake and roasted lamb dish.  These are melt-in-your-mouth good.  It comes with a rice pilaf which is tasty and an ordinary diner-type salad.  Oh yeah I really enjoyed their tea.  No booze according to their tradition, but go and try the tea.  If you must have booze, try take out.
author: John Y.

description:
I signed up as a Yelp member JUST so that I could write a rave review for this place. I've eaten there two nights in a row and can honestly say it's the best Middle Eastern food I've had in the city.

The owners are so gracious and nice and helpful, and each dish has a distinctly amazing flavor.

We ordered the appetizer platter (baba ghanouj, hummus, cucumber yogurt, and tabouleh). Being obsessed with all of the above, I was blown away at the freshness, and totally unique flavor. The yogurt and cucumber dish is the best I've ever had.

The "mango juice" is literally about 4 mangos blended and poured in a cup.

Baklava- perfectly sweet but not too much, not too oily.

Lentil soup- spiced masterfully and not the usual bland brown mush that most lentil soups tend to be.

I made sure to compliment the chef, which I have never done in my life.
author: Emily P.

description:
I was on my way to Fly to meet up with friends.  
I was there 30 mins before our meeting time so I decided to take a bite at Yemeni's to kill my hunger.

I ordered lentil soup and Yemeni's national dish thingie with vegetarian option.
I really like the lentil soup.  It was watery for my taste but still with solid flavor.   

Major disappointment came when they served me Yemeni's national dish with meat in it.  And how sad and small  the portion over all.  I thought it didn't much up the description of in the menu.

And the flat bread that i did not order was included in the bill.  Yes i ate half of it but no i did not order it and it is not in the menu.  

I left the place feeling I have been ripped off.
It felt very disingenuous when I pointed it out to the guy who was serving me and he just shrugged and walked away.

Next time... well there def. will be no next time.
author: fiona B.

description:
The humus and baba ganoush were delicious. The kofta plate was acceptable, but the meat was on the dry side. The rice was not worth mentioning and the side salad missed any dressing!
The lamb shawarma was put into a pocket pita bread and was just plain boring! 
Very slow service and many things on the menu are not being offered. Keep in mind you have to ask about everything on the menu as the names of their dishes don't have any explanation of what it is in English.
author: Bogee B.

description:
Ive never had Yemeni food, so I wanted to sample something that was a popular Yemeni dish, the waitress recommended the Salteh with bread & meat, she said it's a type of  spicey stew that comes in a boiling hot bowl with meat and flat bread

it looked like a small bowl of green sauce with some lamb meat and spicey seasoning and came with flat bread. Personally I wouldnt recommend this dish unless you like hot spicey bitter flavor, the only thing that was decent was the flat bread, they also charge extra for each piece if you need more bread, I wondered why she kept asking if I needed more bread, I thought it was included with the meal, but they charged extra for each piece.

the menu really needs some improvement, because it's hard to decide what to order unless you know Yemeni dishes and they dont have a good description on the menu, you have to ask the waitress what everything is, they should have a photo of each dish and a better description, no take out menus available either.

I wasnt really impressed but maybe they need more time to improve

the CAFE ZITOUNA Authentic Morrocan cuisine on Sutter st is much better.
author: Mr Bolo B.

description: Wow!!  My wife and I loved this place. We ate here and found it perfect.  The hummus was awesome as was the lamb.  Cheap and overly delicious!!  All the way from Anchorage.... We loved it!
author: Scott B.

description:
Highly recommended! I never cared for Middle Eastern food or lamb, but this place has a fantastic lamb (order Mindhi), excellent pita bread and the best hummus I've eaten.
I would say don't bother reading the menu, because it doesn't really reflect what's being cooked - just ask what they have that day. To me its like a home made food where you ask the cook: so whats for dinner tonight?  I have not yet been disappointed with anything that I ordered there.
author: Maya S.

description:
It's the Grand Opening of a new Mediterranean Place right across the street, so I stopped by to check out what used to be a defunct Chinese restaurant. 

Inside, was a much nicer interior with all the trappings of a typical Middle Eastern restaurant. 

The service was exceptionally attentive and our waitress explained the menu very well. The menu itself, however, needs a little work, as many of the dishes require a good amount of knowledge of the cuisine to understand what you are ordering. In the future, they should write a one line explanation of the dish for nearly everything, especially when the meat is relevant.

The food itself was pretty good. The lamb was savory and I particularly recommend the combination barbeque plate. The kitchen needs to work a bit on timing and temperature control, and some of the standard basics of the business.

Portions are very nice and it is well-priced. 
Expect dinner for two without drinks to run around $20-$25+tip. 

All in all, it's a welcome addition to the neighborhood, and I'm sure that it will only get better with time.
author: David H.

description: Halal meat is served here. Based on Halal Sign on Window. Had the Chicken Ghilaba, which is mainly a breakfast item, but was still great for lunch, as it came with a large plate of chicken pieces and vegetables in a spicy sauce, a big piece of Naan and some chili sauce on the side. I also ordered some Yemeni tea, which as great! very flavorful and sweet.  Plenty of seating inside with nicely decorated interior. Service is friendly.  Prices are reasonable.  I will be back here again when I am in the area.
author: Irfan R.

description:
While I waited for our take out, they gave me some tea which was very good, and I'm not a big tea person. The falafel with hummus was excellent and different than most Ive tasted. It was my first time eating Yemeni style food. They have a big delicious pita they make too. Also different than most pitas I've encountered. We really liked this place and we were lucky to have it right across the street from our Hotel. 
Side note, I got accosted by the SFPD, who were all very polite right out front of this place. I had some marijuana delivered and I guess they thought the deal looked shady. They took my weed and searched the poor delivery guys car, while we were both in handcuffs. The cops later explained that because of the neighborhood we were in (Tenderloin), they had to make sure the deal was legitimate, and not crack or some shit. The SFPD gave me back my stuff and let both of us go on our way... All out front of this great Yemenis restaurant.
author: Sour D.

description: Everything was great. We had a  combo plate of kebabs and a shrimp and rice dish that were both excellent. We tried a dessert that was like a Yemeni version of bread pudding with dates, bananas, and cream and it was wonderful in taste and texture. Service was also excellent. The owner stopped by and was very charming and welcoming. We loved this place.
author: Rob K.

description:
Freshly baked pita bread!  

Yemeni's Restaurant should have a blinking neon sign that says "Hot Pita Bread Now!"

I didn't see what I wanted on the menu, so I told the waitress what I wanted and she got it for me for $5.   She brought a combination of hummus, baba ghanouj, tabbouleh salad, and yogurt salad, along with a large HOT, freshly baked piece of pita bread (or the Yemeni equivalent).  Everything was delicious.  

The waitress was American, but had a nice costume that included a head scarf.  I thought she was a pale Yemeni at first.   

The service was good.  While the waitress was serving another table, a meth addict came in and was trying to get into the refrigerator where the soft drinks are kept.  The waitress politely asked her what she needed, and when the meth addict said "beer", the waitress said, "We don't serve alcohol here".  

Duh!  It's a Yemeni restaurant!   The Lower Polk neighborhood doesn't need any more alcohol.  There are enough meth addicts, too.   More Yemenis would be good.
author: Emma Q.

description: I would say this is one of "must-try" places in San Francisco. Food is amazing!!! The best Middle Eastern I've ever had, outside of Middle East. I've dined in as well as take-outs numerous times, and I have never disappointed. Lastly, I recently ordered for twenty people and they gave us lots of food. Again the food was excellent and everyone was so satisfied, and had food-coma!!! This place is a local gem. I love it.
author: MASATO K.

description:
Very delicious and authentic flavors. We had maqluba (#23?). It was a grilled beef that was exquisitely seasoned and prepared, with a bed of basmati rice. Large portions. 

Also had a Spicy basmati rice casserole dish with marinated beef chunks (sorry, forgot name, maybe kabsah, #26? It had the option of beef or chicken). This beef was so tender, like beef brisket. Sooo addictive.

Lamb is a must have here. Tender, fragrant, not gamey b/c it is so well-prepped. The waitress recommended the lamb dish we had, a bone-in lamb (generous pieces of the rib section). Yummy!

My friends loved an okra dish we had here. Cooked well, not slimy like okra sometimes is.

The flatbread that comes with dishes like hummus is piping hot and freshly made. Everything was very fresh actually.
*Tip: Don't refrigerate leftover bread. Keep it wrapped. Heat in oven at 350 degrees covered in foil for three-four minutes. Good as new!

Try the hot tea if you like sweet cinnamon flavors.

The owner recommended a bread pudding  type dish for dessert that my friends loved. I saw mention of it in another yelper's review. Lovely dates and currants in it and interesting crunchy texture that western bread puddings don't have.

I've been twice and both times were delicious. The restaurant sadly was pretty empty both times, but the few other diners there were raving about the food. The ambiance is casual - probably was a Chinese restaurant in a previous life. I will say it looks like the owner has done some remodeling in the last month - Chinese lanterns replaced with regular lamps. That's a good move. This is not a date spot by any stretch of the imagination - it's in the Tenderloin, so don't come here by yourself at night. (For those not familiar with what to expect in the Tenderloin: A random guy sat on the hood of my car and asked for $5 to "watch" it for me. If I weren't from Memphis, I would have been scared.)  If coming in the morning, call ahead to make sure they are open - once they weren't ready at 11:30am on a Friday, but maybe that was an off day. On this Friday morning, their doors were wide open.

Come here if you want to try delicious, authentic Middle Eastern food at a reasonable price (entrees around $10-$14).
author: B B.

description: When you have tried as many cuisines as I have, it gets harder and harder to find something new.  I was glad to have tried Yemenis cuisine.  Definitely try Salteh which is something like their national dish and a sumptuous and hearty lamb dish.  This place is located in TenderNob on a corner which can be described as slowly developing to Islam central.  So if you are an adventurous eater and not worried that you might be dining with Al Qaeda and that you will be tagged by Homeland Security, go and try something new.
author: Laurence H.

description: Pretty solid service. Super spicey. Delicious stones chicken dish. Very aromatic and unique flavors. No booze, quite traditional Yemeni's cuisine. Nice atmosphere. Would go back, but would avoid their signature stew... way too spicy!
author: Jordan S.

description: Amazing food, good value and very kind service. The ambiance is a little dated, but the food is worth it. Just a note - they do not serve alcohol, so for us it's a better place to dine on the week days.
author: Sarah Louise H.

description:
I hate to say it, but I think most of the people who rated this place highly don't know what Arabic food is supposed to taste like.  

Food:  3 of us ordered different dishes.  Friend #1 got the Yemeni soup, which he reported to be good.  He also got a lamb dish that he barely picked at, even after a day of fasting.  Makes me think it wasn't very good.  Friend #2 got the equivalent of lamb chops and liked it, but I think his standards are pretty low.  I ordered the chicken shawarma plate, on my continued quest to find good shawarma in the city.  No luck!  It was wrong on so many levels.  Even the rice was not anywhere near authentic.  My friend got the Turkish coffee and he was served a dirty little mug, which I ended up cleaning for him. 

The service: there were 2 waitresses, one who knew nothing about the dishes and spoke little English (the boys I was with guessed she was Russian) and another who was nice enough, but the service was still pretty bad.  

Suffice it to say that I will not be returning and I will continue to search for good Arabic food in SF!
author: goph s.

description:
I am so addicted to this restaurant.  My boyfriend and I went back here Friday night we started off with middle eastern tea (very food tea! with a hint of cinnamon) and for appetizer we had the hummus and bread (always good) fresh baked, and this time he had the Chicken Schwerma Enteree served with rice and salad, and I had the Prawn Ghilabi it's saute shrimp with saute vegetables served with rice, these two dish were amazing.  You have to try these two dish it's to die for! 

And for dessert we decided to try I think it's like bread pudding it has bananas, chopped dates and chopped nuts, drizzled with honey and cream.....OMG! I am in love with this dessert.  I'm not sure what it's called but I think is Fattah, this is a must try.  If you order this dessert it's good for 4-5 people it's pretty big portion.  I will have this dessert again.

The owner is such a sweet person and our waitress was so nice and attentive.  All the staff there is the nicest people I've ever met.  Every time I come here they are always so nice! This is my favorite Mediterranean restaurant and will not go to another.  I've been recommending this place to all my co-workers, friends and family.

Don't even ask for alcohol drinks they do not serve any type of alcohol.
author: Cece C.

description:
I had the stewed fava beans that I can't remember the name of. I love fava beans and these did not disappoint. I slurped down a huge pile of them and would have licked the takeout box if I hadn't been in polite company. I had tandoor bread with them, which wasn't amazing (a little on the chewy side) but it didn't matter, because it was coated in fava beans. My friend had chicken shwarma, which I tried, and thought was fine, but I am neither a great lover nor an expert on chicken shwarma, so it made me shrug my shoulders like it usually does. 

I thought prices were very reasonable, especially for vegetarian dishes. I think mine was under $6?! I'm not sure why this place is getting two dollar signs.
author: Julia G.

description: I am Middle Eastern but I never had Yemeni food before and I was thoroughly impressed. I went to this place yesterday and the food was excellent. The food definitely had authentic spices and it was unlike any Arabic restaurant that I've been to. You should definitely try the Tanoor bread which is like the bread that they make in Iraq and  it's quite similar to Indian Nan. They also serve a Yemeni flat bread called Malawah which is very good. Before I received my main course they brought a Yemeni soup which was very good. Next time I go there I will definitely go for a  large order of their soup. The Lamb Mandi is to die for. On top of that the owner is very gracious and friendly.
author: Bashar Z.

description:
First time I went there and I had the hummus, yemeni's special soup and the grilled lamb dish. Everything was really good and the portion are pretty big. I was surprised my bill came up to $20 ordering 2 dishes and an appetizer with couple breads.

Service is good. It's a low key but friendly place. I'll def stop by again!
author: Christian P.

description: I LOVE THIS PLACE!!! My sister and I came here a little over a week ago and FELL IN LOVE!  The food was amazing (first time trying Yemeni food) and came in generous servings.  Everybody that works here was incredibly friendly and helpful, especially the owner.  The owner was so attentive and seemed very delighted that we were really enjoying ourselves.  The Meza combo was to die for, the hummus was the best I have ever tasted and the falafel !!! YUMMY!  We both ordered our own entrees however I cannot remember the names of what we ordered! LOL Regardless it was ALL GOOD and I definitely will be coming back :)
author: Diana K.

description: The food there was so bad, definitely not worth what we paid, took the waitress 2 mins to get our food after we ordered which was an indication that it was not fresh and just microwave heated.  The meat was old, dry and crunchy,  not tasty, not authentic and the rice was so dry and crunchy and old.  The yogurt cucumber salad had hardly any cucumber taste and was very thick, like also old.  We came all the way from LA to try this restaurant and were very very disappointed. We will never go back here again.  I'm sure all the previous good reviews written are from people employed at this place or friends of the owner trying to pump up the star ratings for the owner.  If you ever experience an authentic yemeni restaurant in Chicago, NY or the Gulf region you will know that what he serves there is not close to what it should taste like and is a major disappointment to his region.
author: Eman N.

description:
This place is great! their flat bread is AMAZING.  I am a vegan and I have lots of veg friends and everyone is always able to find something here.  I believe they have a separate menu for vegetarians even.  I wish it would come up when you do a search for vegan bc it doesn't disappoint!

I got take out and it fed me for 3 full meals because the portions were so big!
author: stephanie r.

description: I have eaten here once, after passing it 100's of times over the years. The food is really good, and the prices are reasonable.  The service is fantastic. I will be back.
author: Bob b.

description:
Yemeni's? More like Yumeni's. 

We stopped by here on the strength of the Yelp reviews. Pretty low-key, low ambiance place which pretty much fits our perfect place to eat. Of course, that's if the food is good. And it is!

We only ordered two things, the "National Dish of Yemen," Salteh. Didn't know there was a national dish of Yemen but now we do. It was all quite good. I expected it to be way more packed with vegetables but the flavors were killer. Maybe ordering it with the lamb is more typical, dunno. And we ordered the fool, too. Now that, my friends, was fantastic. Just fantastic.

I'd go here again in a heartbeat and, since they don't serve alcohol (is that a license thing or a cultural thing?) the bill was $12.00! How can you beat that?
author: Rusty K.

description: This review is for a takeout order of the salteh.  The stew was flavorful and full of veggies and very tender meat.  The crowning glory was the hulba - a green sauce made with fenugreek and cilantro - very assertive but not spicy - and perhaps not for the faint hearted but just delicious!
author: Ash A.

description: Great find. Cheap, unique menu, true to Yemeni roots. Very friendly staff and nice decor.
author: Max M.

description:
I've been here twice. I was kinda turned off from going in because it doesn't look like much from the outside, but it's actually comfortable and clean inside. 

I've ordered to-go both times, so not sure about their table service. The menu is a little confusing if you're not familiar with Yemeni food(im not), so I asked the non-yemeni server for some recommendations. On her rec, I got the lamb kofta, ground seasoned lamb with rice and salad, the yogurt with cucumber (delish!) and some sort of stew and flat bread.

I loved everything I got and thought it was reasonably priced and was ready in about 15 minutes and more than enough for two people.

I'd definitely keep going back.
author: Kathy K.

description: We discovered this place when we needed to have a quick dinner before going to a class on Bush Street.  What a wonderful surprise.  Now it is our weekly stop.  The food is delicious.  It was great to try something different from the Middlle East.  They have wondeful breads; you can get hummus with lamb in it.  The hot sauce is not harissa like Morocco, it  really packs a punch.  The tea is yummy too.  A good wake up that we need for an evening class.  Wish we did not have to always eat in a rush.
author: Molly B.

description: I visited this place with my dad. The food is great. I had chai too which was different than any chai I have tried. The ambiance is cool. I feel like being  in yamn
author: Wada W.

description: I stopped by here while waiting on my sister. It was very quiet and I was the only one there eating. I tried the Kufta. It was soo good! I usually don't even like lamb but after reading some reviews about the lamb I had to try it. The lamb was soo goooood! Can I emphasize GOOD?? The service is good. The waitress was very helpful since it was my first time having Yemen food. Definately come back to this place if I'm ever in the area.
author: Tiff C.

description: Stopped in for a meal while staying nearby. Premises were quiet early on a rainy Wednesday evening. While somewhat mid-eastern in flavor, Yemeni food has more peppery spice with mild bitterness that is uniquely delivered in frothy, steaming salteh stew. With lamb, this was a hearty meal. Flatbread and a fiery relish came on the side. Great on a cool evening and opened the sinuses. Service was good, though young waitresses were engaged in phone conversations in between attending to customers.
author: Randall L.

description: Great middle eastern food for reasonable prices. Large portions, too. I got the traditional soup and and lamb. Was delicious.
author: stuart l.

description: Two stars instead of one because the server was very sweet, the milk tea is delicious, and the appetizer platter was passable. However, the rest of the food was one star--extremely bland and the meat was fatty and obviously cheap.
author: Krista W.

description: Incredible price for value/deliciousness ratio. Saha can suck it.
author: Ara S.

description: Ordered for delivery and it was horrible!  All the various meat dishes were way overcooked and dry and tough.  The lentil soup was dry!!  Seriously, no liquid, just paste.  The rice was dry and almost hard.  Ended up throwing out most of the food and won't order from there again.
author: Pam B.

description:
I have now eaten here about 10 times since my first review. This is really the best testimony that I can give to how good the food is. Ali is truly wonderful to speak with. He is always so gracious and kind and loves to comp tasty little treats...so why the drop of a star?

The prices went up...or rather (as I was told) they started charging the the menu prices. I will still eat here because you really can't find flavor like this just anywhere. In all honesty, the prices really reflect how good the food is, it's just hard to pay more when I have paid less. 

I will sum it up by saying that the drop in a star really reflects my expectation differential. Who knows, my expectations may change again and they'll get their hardest won star back.
author: Kane M.

description: I love the foul here! I have been obsessively stalking it since I discovered this hole-in-the-wall restaurant. I've tried some of the other dishes, and they're just ok in comparison. Portions are large, although the mixed app. dish was a lil' skimpy (and sadly uneventful). Last gripe - service is really off and awkward. I wouldn't bring a date, but bring your friends and family!
author: Minnie P.

description:
I have no idea how I found this place.  I'm even more amazed because every time I try to go, I nearly miss it.  I think my boyfriend said that it was award-winning and of a cuisine of which we had not yet partaken and I said, "Yea verily, omnomnom."  That's what I say to most dinner suggestions, come to think of it.

I've been a couple times now, and it's never full.  There are only ever one or two other groups in the restaurant, and it's always nice and quiet.  The atmosphere is very casual, though I do like to stare at the carved wood throughout.  It's pretty, but also very homey.  The combination of decor and emptiness make it feel like Yemeni's Restaurant is really mine, and I like that.

So what's Yemeni food like, you may ask?  Well, it's surprisingly like other Mediterranean/Middle Eastern food.  You have your large, mostly-flat, delightfully-somewhat-charred-but-otherwise-squishy bread, your hummus, dolmades, yogurt sauce, tabouleh, baba ganoush, etc.  In fact, if you get the mezza plate, you can get all of those things!  And also the "mossaka," which is sort of like a cross between what you normally think of as "moussaka" without the bechamel, and baba ganoush.  It's really, really good.  I always fill up on this stuff and then remember that I have a main dish coming.  And as good as these little treats are, the entrees are where it's at.  You can get your standard couscous, kebabs, or schawerma, and those are all good.  But!  If you want to be really legit, you should get the Yemeni national dish, or the foul.  I don't recall what all is in the national dish, but it comes to you in a stone pot, bubbling away.  You can have it vegetarian or with lamb, and it's about the most comforting meal you could have - except for the foul.  Foul is a traditional Middle Eastern dish containing fava beans, tomatoes, a ton of garlic, and not a ton of oil.  It also contains joy, rainbows, and sunshine.  Really.  I looked back in the kitchen and saw jars labeled with all those things.  And once you taste it, you'll see that's the only possible way it could taste so good.  It's filling-but-healthy, and just feels really good to eat.  Scoop it up with huge hunks of that awesome flatbread, and feel the warmth penetrate.

In addition to being a quiet place, Yemeni's Restaurant is also a friendly place.  They have a vegetarian menu for which you'll need to ask, but the servers happily provides that and anything else you'd like.  More bread?  Certainly!  More bread to go with your leftovers?  That's fine, too.  The service isn't always very prompt but since you're probably going to be the only one in there, you can't necessarily expect them to be perpetually on their toes.  I've never had to wait any amount of time that was unreasonable, either.  And really, this isn't a place you want to go to in a hurry, anyway.  Enjoy the private dining, the hot food, and the friendly ambiance.  Siddown.  Stay a while.  Gorge.  Repeat.
author: Becca S.

description:
DELICIOUS!!!! 
I go here for lunch about twice a week since I work nearby. I am hopelessly hooked on their meze plate. I have never liked hummus but their's is out of this world. Soups and BBQ fantastic. Salads good too. 
The chef is wonderful, and the food is always fresh. 
So glad they are in the neighborhood. 
YUM! 
:-)
author: Rita F.

description: #1 REAL MIDDLE EASTERN RESTAURANT IN THE BAY AREA. Food is full of flavor. try out Mandi, Mathbi and Kulaba.  After that try out the tea with milk. I love this place
author: Motaz H.

description: I've only eaten there once so far and, despite the two-star rating, I'll probably try them again.  I ordered the lamb mandi, because it was described as a traditional Yemeni dish and I wanted something other than the usual Mediterranean suspects like shwarma, falafel, or kababs.  I was pleased by how moist and tender the meat was but disappointed by its mild flavor.  The accompanying rice and salad were fine but nothing to write home about.  Service was good.
author: Cindi L.

description:
Put it this way: my taste buds danced. The delicate seasonings were gently infused into each dish. I had a special chicken dish with the best rice - think it was jasmine flavored. I have been to this restaurant a few times. Each time, the staff is very nice. To finish, I had the tea with a tea cake. Yummy! 


You have to try this place. The food is delicious! 

I will return again!
author: Candace d.

description: Terrible food. Every meat dish I ordered was overcooked! This is not Yemini food. I think it might be more classified as general middle-of-the-road middle eastern food. It's also run by one of the few english speaking Yemini members of the Masjid Al-Twaleed mosque up the street.  So many mosque members have opened restaurants in the Polk Street area, it's hard to keep track of them. They open and close within months over and over again.
author: Tony G.

description: Tasty food. I had the appetizer sampler, Meza, and it was very good. It was served with bread which was phenomenal. I should've ordered more of the bread. The place was pretty deserted maybe because there is no bar. Didn't bother me a bit.
author: Richard M.

description: Pretty good (light) chicken shawarma wrap.  Best I've had in the city in years!
author: F K.

description: I had this review written months ago, but as I haven't written too many reviews, I hadn't saved nor posted it.....Wow....this place was the best!  We went for lunch. We walked in and were warmly greeted.  The waitress told us to sit where we'd like.  She brought us this amazing tasting tea in these little clear glass cups. For an Aghan it is important to be served tea in a clear cup or it just isn't right.  The owner came and greeted us too.  He spoke to my husband as if they had known each other...it was nice.  We had the combination kabob...it melted in your mouth...yum!  We complemented the tea and the owner brought us a whole tea kettle.  After our meal the owner brought us some baklava and cookies...on the house...which was very nice. All in All 5 stars for the food, 5 stars for the service, 5 stars for the hospitality.  The owner treated us as if we were guests in his home and that is just good old Mulsim hospitality...Thanks.  Definately recommend this place.  Can't wait to try the Salteh next time.
author: HAWA A.

description: Please try this restaurant as food is phenomenal.  We ordered 3 different lamb dishes on the menu and all were tasty and juicy.  As a new restaurant, this places needs as much support as it can get to stay in business.  I like yemeni food because it is refreshing and isn't greasy.
author: anita c.

description: this is a great lunch spot!  the prices are reasonable (just under $8 for a wrap) and the  service is excellent.  plus, the food is delicious.  get the chicken!  it's cooked perfectly.
author: Christy C.

description: I went to this restaurant yesterday. I waited for 30 minutes for somebody to take my order. They gave me water with no glasses they gave me food with no silverware they gave me no plates to put my food. I ordered okra and the okra was hard and cold. They give me rice that appeared to be cooked the previous day which was hard. I told the waitress who was also the cashier and she didn't she did not do anything about it. I also ordered bread which never arrived to the table.
author: Anthony G.

description: Great place for authentic middle eastern food. The manager/owner even came by to see how we were doing and if we needed anything. Even though it was crowded on a Thursday we got awesome service and food. I'm a fan :D
author: Queencie P.

description: We stayed nearby and thought we would try it---never had Yemenese food.  We ordered several appetizers and dishes to share family style.  Everything was delicious.  The Saltah is  my new favorite comfort food.  Friendly service and very good prices (esp for SF).  Would highly recommend.
author: Daniette H.

description: This place is off the hook!!! The food is so delicious . Love the lamb dish , the bread so soft . I try different items on the menu everything is so tasty and delightful. Everyone who works there is so friendly with a smile on their face. The food is always fresh and there are alot of vegan choices. I am definetly a fan.
author: Cindi S.

description:
Terrible! Every meat dish we ordered was overcooked! This is not a Yemini cusine, this is a generic middle eastern restaurant. 

If you want to see what Yemeni cuisine is http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yemeni_cuisine
author: Mohammad A.

description: I got takeout here with my girlfriend. We arrived a little early and had a seat at the bar. On a whim, we decided to get some custard and they offered us some free tea. It was quite nice and when our food came out we was anxious to get home and try it considering the pleasant experience we had while waiting. Basically, we were disappointed. It wasn't bad; just mediocre.
author: Stephen C.

description: This Yemenese restaurant (the first I have ever been to) has just opened.  I found the owners cordial and warm, eager to share the cuisine of their country.  I ordered a type of meat-bean stew, which came with a sizable portion of juicy, fresh lamb, and an enormous flatbread, as well as some mint tea and baklava.  Everything was very fresh and delicious, and it is obvious the owners and staff take great pride in their work.  Very reasonably priced.  Go support this new gem.
author: Nick H.

description:
We had a great experience here. Showed up with my husband, son, and my parents from out of town: the friendly (and very cute) servers were happy to accommodate our two year old, knowledgable about the menu, and attentive all evening.

The food is mostly your standard Middle Eastern fare: kebobs, shawarma, tabouleh, hummus, baba ghanous -- with a few specifically Yemeni dishes like Salteh added. My mom got the lamb salteh: it's a very spicy stew of vegetables and (if you like) meat, served bubbling hot in a clay pot. She thought it was fantastic. She likes spicy food and is rarely served dishes that she finds hot enough for her taste. I'm a spice wimp -- I took one bite and was glad I'd gotten a kebob!

My husband said his shawarma was pretty average and I'd say the same about my kebob. But the whole table raved about our appetizer combo platter (baba ghanous, hummus, tabouleh, and yogurt/cucumber sauce--I think of it as raita even though it probably has a special Yemeni name). Everything was fantastic. The hummus especially stood out: silky, tangy, much MUCH better than the bland chickpea paste you often get. The baba ghanous was comparable to what you get at A La Turca, which is my gold standard for the stuff, and the fluffy, nutty-tasting bread is very good too: it's more rustic than what they serve at A La Turca, I think it has a higher proportion of whole grains, which is good. My son loved it, and the servers brought out more whenever we were running low.

I was really surprised at how good the raita was, because normally I can take or leave the stuff. I wonder if they use a special yogurt as the base? We all enjoyed the appetizers so much that we also ordered a plate of olives and a plate of cheese, two bucks each for good-sized little plates. 

We'll definitely come back to Yemeni's. The dining space is nice and inviting, if you can get over the cheesy Chinese lanterns left over from the previous owners. We liked the young international crowd that the restaurant seems to attract. Next time we come I'm really tempted to make a small-plates meal out of the appetizers, since they're so good and very reasonably priced.
author: Shannon P.

description: Everything was really good. I think I got the Chicken Kabob, which reminded me of Persian food. My friend got Salteh, which was pretty damn good, but not spicy at all. I want to say we got the Fattoush as an appetizer, but whatever it was, none of us could stop eating that stuff!!! The tea was awesome. My friends BF got one of the lamb dishes, which I didn't like as much, but it was still good.
author: Ken L.

description: Good food and friendly service - Yemini's still has a few bumps to overcome but they're on their way. The owner maintains a presence which is nice. A menu with pictures would be very helpful. The hot tea is delicious!
author: James P.

description: Lamb dish was fantastic. Friendly atmosphere.
author: Emre A.

description: I've wanted to eat here for months and this past Wednesday night I finally did. The Maza platter is a great appetizer that has all your favorites to put on their fresh flat-bread.  It's a meal in itself. For dinner we had the mixed grill platter which comes with chicken, lamb, rice and salad.  For $24 it's an amazing meal that will fill up two people and you get to try almost everything on the menu.  Great food, great deal and great service.  I'll be back for sure.
author: Corey V.

description: Best lamb I've ever had. You need to get the Mindi!
author: Sue G.

description: Finlay we have Yemeni food in San Francisco i like there MANDY MEAT with rice ,what you should tray is the fish they cook it in very nice way, i like this place
author: naser a.

description: Good portions, good service, good location!  The owner and his family came off as unwelcoming and suspicious but the waiter who is Tajik is very nice and humble.
author: AJ B.

description: Best Middle Eastern Food and incredibly reasonable prices. Ask about the specials--they are terrific. Something for everyone here, from carnivore to vegetarian. Beautifully prepared, generous portions. The tab shockingly low! Service is a little rough around the edges, but the staff are all helpful and friendly. The mixed BBQ platter - chicken, lamb kebab and lamb kibbe - superb. Meza platter - to die for! Fresh-baked tandoor bread, so yummy! For dessert, try the layered Yemeni flat bread, buttered and drizzled with honey. Splendid!!!! Can't wait to go back next time I'm in SF. We ate there 2 nights in a row--no reason to go elsewhere! They don't serve alcohol, so get your pre- and post-dinner libations across the street at the Fly bar.
author: Jennie M.

description: Lentil soup is excellent - hints of cinnamon and some kind of squash. Dolmas are surprisingly well spiced - a warm flavor burst in your mouth. The falafel were refreshingly filling without being heavy or oily (no bread filler here, folks). And the baklava were heavily honey'd, wonderfully spiced, and chock-full of nutty goodness. This restaurant is being added to one of my favorite lunch/work spots!
author: Alex M.

description: I love this place and always go when family is in town because you get a lot of really good food for a reasonable price. Fresh, clean, and delicious ingredients every time.
author: Cheryl C.

description: One of the hidden gems of the TenderNob!  Wonderful food - I especially like the lentil soup and the chicken kabsah.  Every dish is very flavorful and the owner is very gracious - always taking the time to greet us and thank  us for coming in.
author: Priti M.

description:
This is an interesting place.  I tried it just tonight, and have to say that the food is pretty good and the service is fast.  I had a very nice young lady as my waitperson, and she is a native English speaker.  Not that it should matter or not, but it is convenient for those who want to get further explanation about what is on the menu.

But this place seems to be a bit mismanaged in other areas.  When I first came in, I was greeted and seated right away... but there were no menus available.  Wha?  They couldn't seem to drum one up for several minutes, and at one point one of the waiters came over and asked if I wanted to order without one.  Wha ??  How can I know what to order without a menu?

The rice wrapped grape leaves was $3.50 and very, very small.  The saving grace for the whole meal was the fact that I ordered the combo grill special as my entree, which was good.  It had kefta, beef, and chicken, all deliciously grilled and tasty on a bed of rice, all with a salad on one plate.

The prices here are reasonable, though I can't recommend the sides like the dolma... I'd stick with the entrees.

I am a fast eater, and the waitress asked if I was done when I still had a bit of food left on my plate.  I like that she is efficient and quick, but some eaters might be annoyed by it.  Personally, I don't mind, but take note.  

And at the end, when I paid in cash, they had absolutely no coins in change, so they just bumped my bill down to the nearest dollar.  It was a bit strange, because I've never heard of a moderately priced restaurant having no change whatsoever.

I still tipped my waitperson well, because she was nice and the food was pretty decent.  And it did come out very, very fast, which I always like.  Maybe I'll give it another try, but I have to say that I think that Aicha a few blocks down might be a bit better overall, despite the seemingly higher prices.
author: Dave N.

description:
I live in the neighborhood and noticed when Yemeni's opened. I'm so disappointed that I did hit this place up sooner. I wanted to try pretty much every dip on the menu and was prepared to pay $3 each but, when I asked the server, she said the have an off-the-menu appetizer sampler for $8.95. We ordered that and it came with hummus, baba, cucumber/yogurt sauce, tabbouleh, and flat bread. The flat bread is fresh and awesome!! I was in love with their babaganouj and am usually pretty judgemental about it. It was garlicky and had a little extra spice (not heat) that I couldn't put my finger on - but I loved. We also got the spicy cheese appetizer (i wish I could remember what it's called but it has Zahaweg in it) - it was really delicious. We got two entrees. The first was a lamb dish (it's also the first item on the menu but I can't remember the name. It was served with flavorful rice and spiced veggies for $8.95. I had the leftovers for lunch today. YUM. The second was the Salteh with meat and bread. I think this, the baba, and the cheese were my favorite things. The Salteh had pieces of lamb in it along with vegetables in a flavorful green broth. It's served in a clay pot, still boiling, and looks like a witch's cauldron with the green bubbles on top. 

I'd recommend this place to anyone and definitely grab a takeout menu if they have them. The ambiance here is not amazing but the people are friendly and the food is cheap and delicious!
author: Natalie G.

description: Went here for the first time today. The food is tremendous and the chef came out and greeted us at lunch time to apologize for our last 2 dishes being late. The Yemenese bread is so great and fresh. I had the lamb wrap. I would come back here again. Food is GREAT!!
author: foodfan k.

description:
Good food, Affordable prices,Friendly service.

Only downside to this place is the constriction you feel because of the small dining space available.
author: Salah Y.

description:
Had dinner with the wife and in-laws.  We came in with high hopes (our own, local, Yemeni restaurant!) and left feeling a little cheated.  

Good food, but expensive, considering the small portions. The owner/manager was very nice and wanted to ensure that everyone was happy.  I liked that.  He brought us free baclava for dessert.  Tasty.

I just felt like the food was O.K., but not worth the price.  You could probably get the same going to a hole-in-the-wall, versus a restaurant.
author: Ryan G.

description: This place is an awesome addition to the neighborhood and has the most amazing chai.  I did not know quite what to expect but I would categorize it as Turkish with a twist.  We ordered the meza appetizer, all the standards (hummus, etc) were spot on and I really liked the second eggplant thing.  Both our entrees were great, I had the lamb stew and my friend had a lamb with rice dish.  The rice was really fragrant and flavorful.  Then we topped it off chai, which was absolutely incredible and a nice way to finish off our leisurely dinner.  Suffice to say I will be coming back.
author: Charley A.

description:
I had a good meal. The complimentary soup was very tasty, the humus was good, but the pita was dry. My shawarma was good but didn't have enough lamb to call it hearty, too much bread. I will go again and order something else. I found the service fine, and I wasn't really worried about the price on the menu. I tried to order the yemen coffee, but was served regular average coffee. They are supposed to be getting new menus in soon. I enjoyed my meal, and I will go back. The restaurant was clean, but it was a bit cold.

I went back here with my family. The falafal is dry and bland. I probably won't go back here.  I lowered my rating to three stars.
author: Andrew Z.

description: This is the best arabic food in the Bay area. Great people too.
author: Tariq A.

description:
It is not that often a new place opens up in the TL which has a bright banner across the entrance saying GRAND OPENING. A friend and I decided to try it. 

The décor is definitely decent, a step up from competing TL places having a similar type of food. The person greeting us (we ignorantly assume) was from Yemen and overly polite which us grumpy Americans don't come across too often. (nice change)

We sit down and start to contemplate the menu. This was the first menu I have struggled with in quite a long time so we had plenty of questions for the waitress. 

We ordered the recommended Salteh with Lamb and the Mixed appetizer plate. The appetizer plate was nice with some of the better dips around.  

The Salteh arrived and it was something very different than what I/we was envisioning. We did our very best to give it a fair chance at a good review. But to tell you the truth, it was not anything I would ever order again. It was a bit on the (welcomed) spicy side and kind of like a potato soup colored green. No fireworks when it comes to flavor is what I am trying to say. The restaurant must of got our order wrong because there was no lamb in the dish at all.

The thing that bothered us was the carafe of water they bring to the table. They put cucumber, and lemon slices in it.  My friend who does this at home noticed immediately that there was no taste to the water and without a doubt there should have been. He suspects they are filling the carafes and not replacing the slices. In other words, our first water came, the slices looked all worn out (not freshly cut), and the water had no taste. That is, we suspect the taste from the slices were used up by previous customers then we walked in and took over the same water carafe.

I guess, all in all, the place was not a repeat for us only because of that.  Maye next year we will try it again and give them a chance to tune things.
author: Jon I.

description: Loved this place - great inexpensive food, awesome hot tea and they even made my falafel gluten free. Unbeatable. The rice is amazing.
author: Mar R.

description:
Went there for dinner on a Saturday night. My husband and I were pleasantly surprised at how delicious the food was. This place recently opened, and we are really rooting for it to take off.
Our waiter was extremely sweet, and seemed like he was still learning the ropes, but we asked him for suggestions and he was very helpful and polite.
We had an appetizer salad that was very fresh and light, with Sahawiq cheese with bread. The cheese was awesome! It wasn't too cheesy, it was more of a spicy sauce with bits of fresh feta cheese.
My husband had the Yemeni Salteh with lamb and bread. It came out in a black cast iron pot, and was still at a roaring boil. It was full of flavor and the lamb was so tender. There were also some veggies in it (more of a stew). 
I had the Kufta plate. The plate had spiced meatballs of lamb (and maybe some beef), on top of rice, and a side of veggies (which I thought needed a pinch of salt). The meatballs were soooooo good! 
We will definitely be back for dinner. 
Also, the interior is much nicer than I thought it would be.
author: Debbie R.

description: Destinational was originally going to be Saha however that place is inside of a hotel so we thought it was weird and looked across the st. Debated, checked yelp, decent reviews, DONE. Let's go! Walked in, NO ONE! We looked at each other and thought, oh well, we'll see. The service wasn't super fast but we weren't in a hurry. The waitress informed us that there was no alcohol and that it would get full after prayer at the Mosque (hence the empty restaurant). Anyway....the food came out quite quickly and it was AMAZING and super reasonably priced. I had never had Yemeni (?) food and I will definitely be going back to this place and am so glad we decided to go for it! I love suprises like that! I'm spreading the word!
author: Monique P.

description: yumm, I had the haneed, and it was super tasty.  service is slow, but the food was great.
author: Seghel Y.

description: this place is awesome!!!! the food is amazing and fresh.......and the service is great....its nice to have another HALAL resturant in town...the place is beautiful and they have a private family area in the back....perfect for dates or family.....
author: Piper a.

description: I have tried this former Chinese restaurant twice and just love it.  The waitress if really helpful and knowledgeable about the various Middle Eastern dishes.  The food is amazing, fresh and really different, especially the Yemini stew.  This place offers good sized portion and incredible value for the quality of the food, give it a try!
author: Jeff R.

description: Excellent food, friendly staff, and great prices. Must try dining adventure in SF. This place inspired me to create a Yelp account.
author: Samuel V.
